loans.name: Agatha

texts.en:
Agatha M. sells bread and flour at Prospect Hill. Agatha has received Senior High education. She is married and has 2 dependents. Her husband is a chemical seller.

Agatha has been selling bread and flour since 2001. She is responsible for paying school fees and other household expenses. Her loan will be used to buy more flour, an oven, oil, and margarine to increase productivity and sales. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest.

loans.use: buy more flour, an oven, oil and margarine

loans.name: Passy

texts.en: N. Passy is 48 years old and lives with her husband.  In 2008 she began her business dealing in clothes. She is using the loan to purchase more clothes such as shirts, pants, material, blankets, etc., for her business located on Herbert Street. Her hope is to increase her daily income and be able to earn more profits.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes such as shirts, pants, material, blankets etc

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia A. M. sells radios, bags, belts, and polish at Abura. Felicia has received Senior High School education. She is married and has 4 dependents. Her husband is a poultry farmer.

Felicia has been selling radios, bags, belts, and polish since 2002. She is responsible for paying school fees and housekeeping expenses. Her loan will be used to buy more radios, bags, belts and polish for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest to expand her business and increase her profit.

loans.use: buy more radios, bags, belts and polish for resale

loans.name: Nzovwe 2 Group

texts.en:
For many years, Frola has been a food seller in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya. She belongs to Nzovwe 2 group loan (Group code 2018). She currently earns very little monthly profit. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.

She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items to add her current stock for the improvement of her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Frola is 34 years old, married, and has five children: ages 15, 14, 12, 10, and 8. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Sophia, who has her own small business, selling food in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more food items to add her current stock

loans.name: Ifuho

texts.en:
Ifuho S. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to open up a charcoal store as a strategic location for sale. She is 30 years old and a mother of three children who all go to school. She is married to a professional primary teacher who teaches in Buluk "A" primary school. With the future profits from her loan, she intends to pay school fees for her children. 

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

 BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: opening up a charcoal store

loans.name: Abudu Salaam

texts.en: Abudu Salaam G. is 34 years-old and a resident of Kyotera who serves on the town council.  He is married man with four children.  Three of his children are in primary school.  He has been dealing with spare parts for over 5 years and he used to operate as mechanic for motorcycles and bicycles. Abudu Salaam will use the loan to purchase spare parts and hopes to expand his business, specifically to capture market even in neighboring districts. His future hopes are to buy a vehicle so that he can transport spare parts to different neighboring districts and also expand the spare part shop to serve the local people.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts so he can expand his business to neighboring districts.

loans.name: Ziada

texts.en: Ziada is a rice seller in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya. She belongs to Kilimahewa 1 group.  She works at her business daily.  She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can  buy more rice for resale. She is hoping that through this loan her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.  Ziada is married and has six children ages 30, 27, 25, 20, and 18.

loans.use: To buy more rice for resale.

loans.name: Oumou

texts.fr:
Madame Oumou Boiré a 41 ans et vit avec son époux et ses 7 enfants (2 garçons et 5 filles), à Wayerma I, le centre ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Oumou  après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, elle s’est initié à cette activité de restauration il y a environ seize ans. Elle mène son activité  à Wayerma I Sikasso devant le domicile conjugal toutes les nuits. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses repas. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant quatre ans. Après 8 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel  et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter, prêt 50kg d’ haricot,  50kg de poissons frais, 30 poulets, 30 sachets d’Attièkè, 20 paquets de spaghetti, 2 sacs de pomme de terre, 20kg d’haricot vert, un stock de banane (Aloko), 5 paquets de cube magie, des sachets de moutarde et un important stocks de condiments. Elle achète ses marchandises sur place, et ses repas sont vendues au comptant ou à crédit  à une clientèle composée de femmes, de célibataires, des jeunes mélomanes du quartier qui sont généralement des noctambules. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 120 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité. 
Son ambition est de rembourser ce prêt avant l’échéance prévue comme le prêt précédent.
texts.en:
Ms. Oumou Boiré, age 41, lives with her husband and her seven children (2 boys and 5 girls) in Wayerma I, the downtown of Sikasso City (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having worked in many kinds of businesses unsuccessfully, she got introduced to the restaurant business about 16 years ago. She operates in Wayerma I Sikasso, there in front of her conjugal home each night. She is in high demand by her customers for the quality of her meals. To satisfy her burgeoning customer base, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso four years ago. After eight solidarity loans (group loans) in a women’s association in her district, she is now on her third individual loan. All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid. She intends to use this loan to buy: 50 kg of beans, 50 kg of fresh fish, 30 chickens, 30 sacks of attièkè (dried fermented cassava), 20 packets of spaghetti, 2 sacks of potatoes, 20 kg of green beans, a stock of bananas (Aloko), 5 packets of Maggi cubes, bags of mustard, and a sizable stock of condiments. She buys her goods locally and sells her meals, cash or credit accepted, to customers composed of women, unmarried people, and young people crazy about music in her area who are generally night-owls. She envisions realizing a monthly profit of 120,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to augment her working capital, to help with family expenses, to make loan interest payments, and to invest the rest in her business. Her ambition is to repay this loan ahead of time, just like the preceding loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients for the restaurant business

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en: Hardworking and industrious Leonida S. is 54 years-old and married, presently living at Clarin in Misamis Occidental province of the Philippines.  She recently joined Paglaum to access financial assistance for her "sari-sari" store, or mini market, to buy additional stock such as laundry items, seasonings, goodies, toiletries, drinks and other household items. She aims to help her husband provide for their family.  She hopes one day to have a successful business with a concrete store and for her children to finish a college degree and have a good future.

loans.use: To but more products for her mini market.

loans.name: Frola

texts.en:
Frola owns a food vendor store in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya. She belongs to the Kilimahewa 1 Group  (Group code 2020).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of  approximately  $430. Every day she works at her store for 12 hours.  

Frola is 40 years old, married, and has six  children: the ages of her first five children are 25, 23, 22, 18  and 7, and she has a sixth younger child.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items to add to her current stock.  She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items to add her current stock, to expand her business.

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Madame Fatoumata Doucouré  a 39 ans  et  3 enfants.  Elle réside avec son époux et leurs  enfants (1garçon et 2 filles) à Wayerma II, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Fatoumata Doucouré après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’initia à  l’activité d’achat et de vente des  friperies   il y a plus de  dix  ans. Elle mène son activité au grand marche de Sikasso où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de  5 ans. Après 4 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier (Association TIESSIRI TON de Wayera II), elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel, tous les prêts précédents ont été  correctement remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter, 4 balles de friperie de qualités différentes (respectivement: Tee-Shirt, Légers, Habits  pour enfants, Draps et Body) sur place avec les grossistes avant de les revendre en détail au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle diverse.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Ms. Fatoumata Doucouré is 39 years old and has three children. She resides with her husband and their children (1 boy and 2 girls) in Wayerma II, a working-class district of Sikasso City (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having worked in many businesses unsuccessfully, she was introduced to buying and selling second-hand clothing over ten years ago. She operates her business at the grand marketplace of Sikasso where she is in high demand by her customers for the quality of her goods. To satisfy her burgeoning customer base, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso over five years ago. After four solidarity loans (group loans) in a women’s association in her district (Association TIESSIRI TON de Wayera II), she is now on her third individual loan. All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid. She intends to use this loan to buy four balls of used clothing of different grades (respectively Tee-Shirt, light-weight, children’s clothing, Draps and Body) locally from wholesalers. She then will sell them retail to a diverse customer base, cash or credit accepted. With this loan, she envisions realizing a monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to augment her working capital, to help with family expenses, to make loan interest payments, and to invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy used clothing

loans.name: Virgilio

texts.en:
"I invested so much in our fishing business. I am a fisherman and my wife and children depend on me to buy the things we need for the house. I am the father and I want to send all my children to school," says Virgilio J., a 33 year-old father of four children.

He would like to ask for a loan of PHP 20,000 from CEVI. He will use the loan to buy fishing materials and to repair the fishing boat. He is also interested to venture into other lines of business.

CEVI provides financial services to rural communities. CEVI gives not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To buy fishing materials and to repair the fishing boat.

loans.name: Dominiciano

texts.en:
"My parents are farmers. They taught me everything about farming so that when I had my own family I could support my wife as well as my children. Now, we are busy preparing our farm for our next planting. Our wish is that we will again have an abundant harvest,“ says Dominiciano S., a father of four children.

He would like to ask for a loan of PHP 7,000 from CEVI. He will use the loan to purchase complete fertilizers, herbicides and ammonium sulfate. He thinks that the loan will help him improve his harvest.

CEVI provides financial services to entrepreneurial poor. CEVI gives not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase complete fertilizers, herbicides and ammonium sulfate for farming.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth sells eggs in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya. She belongs to the Kilimahewa 1 Group (Group code 2020).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of  approximately  $330. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.  

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she  can buy more eggs for resale. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.  

Ruth is 45 years old, married, and has five  children, ages 30, 28, 25, 24, and 20.

loans.use: To buy more eggs for resale.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en: Jocelyn G. is 28 years old, married, and lives in Tudela, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She joined Paglaum Cooperative in April 2009 in order to enjoy the financial assistance and the programs and services they offer. She requests a loan of Php5,000.00 for her sari-sari store. She will use the loan to buy additional stocks, such as laundry items, seasonings, goodies, toiletries, drinks and other household items. She aims to have a successful business in a concrete building and hopes that her children can finish their college degrees and have good futures.

loans.use: additional capital for sari-sari store

loans.name: Ramatou

texts.fr:
Née le 02 Juin 1967 à Bobo Dioulasso (au Burkina Faso), Ramatou O. est mariée et mère de six enfants (2 garçons et 4 filles). Elle vit avec son époux et leurs enfants  à Hamdallaye, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Ramatou mène une activité d’achat et de vente de condiments alimentaires il y a plus d’une décennie.  Elle a fait ses débuts depuis très jeune auprès de sa maman. 
C’est pour devenir une grossiste en ravitaillant les détaillantes du  marché qui ont souvent du mal à s’approvisionner facilement, qu’elle décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant six ans. Après plusieurs  prêts solidaires (prêt du groupe) avec une association des femmes à Kadiolo Noumousso elle est maintenant au 3ème prêt individuel, tous ses prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce présent prêt, elle compte acheter, 5 cartons de magie, 10 cartons de  concentrée de tomate, 4 sacs d’oignon séchés, 2 sacs de graine de poivre, 2 sacs de feuilles de laurier, 5 cartons de moutarde et d’importants stocks d’autres condiments au grand marché de Sikasso. Elle compte revendre ses marchandises en gros au comptant et à crédit à ses camarades détaillantes du nouveau marché de Médine où elle mène son activité. 
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  ses  propres dépenses, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born on June 2, 1967 in Bobo Dioulasso (in Burkina Faso), Ramatou O. is married and the mother of six children (2 boys and 4 girls). She lives with her husband and their children in Hamdallaye, a working-class district of Sikasso City (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). She has been running a business buying and selling condiments for over a decade. She started off at a very young age at her mother’s side. Wholesalers resupply the retailers at the marketplace who often have trouble stocking up easily. To become a wholesaler, she decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso ten years ago now. After several solidarity loans (group loans) in a women’s association in Kadiolo Noumousso, she is now on her third individual loan. All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid. She intends to use this loan to buy five boxes of Maggi, ten boxes of tomato paste, four sacks of dried onions, two sacks of pepper corns, two sacks of bay leaves, five boxes of mustard, and sizable stocks of other condiments at the grand marketplace of Sikasso. She intends to sell her merchandise in bulk to fellow retailers, cash or credit accepted, at the new marketplace of Médine, where she operates her business. With this loan, she envisions realizing a monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA that will be used to support herself, to help with family expenses, to make loan interest payments, and to invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments

loans.name: Claire

texts.en: Ms. Claire R. has been a member of the Paglaum MPC since April 2009.  She requests a loan of Php5,000.00 to buy more feed and vitamins for her hog-raising project. She is happy with this project as it helps a lot with her daily needs, especially during harvest. She hopes that she will be able to save money in the future and live life to the fullest.

loans.use: to purchase hog feed and vitamins

loans.name: Digna

texts.en:
"I have experienced both good and bad harvest on our farm. My husband and I have been renting the farm for nine years already. Currently, we are in the process of preparing the farm for our next planting. We hope to have an abundant harvest to be able to provide for all our needs. We dream that someday we could buy our own farm and be able to send our children to school,” says Digna.

She would like to ask for a loan of PHP 6,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase certified seeds and fertilizers. She is also interested to venture into other lines of business.

CEVI helps small business grow. CEVI provides not just financial services but also training and insurance coverage

loans.use: To purchase certified seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Robiya

texts.ru:
Козибобоева  Робия 1972 года рождения. Замужем имеет 3 детей. Муж является предпренимателем.  Она дома шьет национальную женскую одежду. У нее много клиентов, особенно весной и летом. Все женщины шьют новые платья по моде. 
Также она разводит дома скот. В бизнесе ей помогают муж и отец. (во время мониторинга Робия была на выезде, на фото отец Робии).
Год назад за кредитом обратилась по совету родителей.  Муж помогает  выводить скот на рынок и прикупать другой скот. Робия благодарна  КИВА за поддержку  в развитии бизнеса.
texts.en:
Robiya K. was born in 1972. She is married and has three children. Her husband is an entrepreneur. She works at home, sewing traditional women's clothing. She has many customers, especially in the spring and summer. All the women tailor new dresses in the latest fashion. She also raises livestock. Her husband and father help with the business (Robiya was out of town when monitoring was done, so her father is pictured in the photograph). She came to us for a loan last year, following the advice of her parents. Her husband helps take the livestock to market and choose new animals. Robiya is grateful to KIVA for supporting her business's development.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising Livestock

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
"When I got married, I experienced emotion because of the many challenges. But my husband is encouraging me to always be strong. Now, we both till the land of 1-hectare. We are renting farmland from a friend. We get a share of every harvest. The more harvest we have, the more our share increases," says Fe A., 48-year old mother of two children. 

She would like to ask for a loan of PHP 7,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase fertilizers, herbicides and molluscide. The loan will also help in the education of her children.

CEVI has been providing financial services to rural communities. CEVI gives not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, herbicides and molluscide for farming.

loans.name: Emmy

texts.en:
Emmy sells rice in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya. She belongs to the Kilimahewa 1 group (Group code 2020).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of  approximately  $250. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.  

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more rice to add her current stock. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.  

Emmy is 43  years old, married, and has four children: ages 27, 25, 22 and 20.

loans.use: To buy more rice to add her current stock.

loans.name: Kiyaga

texts.en: Kiyaga A. is a 50-year-old married man with ten children in school. He operates a retail shop at Kijjabwemi Masaka where he has been selling domestic products since 1990. He is using the loan to purchase retail products such as sugar, maize flour, cooking oil, milk, soap, and paraffin. Because he is the major distributor in his area, he wants to become a wholesaler dealer. Through his business, which is located at Kijjabwemi, he plans on supplying commodities to his community in order to help him increase his daily income.

loans.use: To purchase products such as sugar, maize flour, cooking oil, soap, and paraffin

loans.name: Fred

texts.en: K. Fred is a 30-year-old business man, married with four children. He started his retail business 20 years ago. He is using the loan to purchase retail shop items to sell: drinks (soda, timed juice, packed milk, yoghurt, etc), food like cakes, breads and biscuits, and other items like soap, sugar etc.  His hope for the future is to improve on his sales and profits.

loans.use: To purchase retail items to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase baby dresses and other clothing to sell

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Juliana is an animal keeper. She has owned a small shop in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya for five years. She belongs to the Halengo 1 group loan. She currently earns an average monthly profit of approximately $250. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more avocados for resale. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business. Juliana is 22 years old, married, and has two children of ages 4 and 1.

loans.use: To buy more avocados for resale

loans.name: Charish

texts.en:
"My husband and I have been tilling a 1-hectare farm since the start of our marriage. Until now, we have been working a farm that is not ours, to support our needs. We always hope to have an abundant harvest for our family. The harvest that we get from our farm is what we use to feed and clothe our children," says Charish L., a 22-year-old mother of two children.

She would like to ask for a loan of PHP 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase Urea fertilizers, herbicides and insecticides. The loan will also help to provide for the education of her children.

CEVI helps small business grow. CEVI provides not only financial services but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase Urea fertilizers, herbicides and insecticides.

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en: Julieta B. is from the village of Unidos. She is 46 years old, married, and has two adult children. Julieta raises ducks for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2005, Julieta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. Julieta is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP which will be used to purchase feed and other supplies. This loan will be her 9th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase feed and other supplies

loans.name: Restituta

texts.en:
"I am a food vendor. I have been selling food since my husband left me. I have a previous work experience as a retailer of ready-to wear products. My income is what we use to buy our needs," says Restituta B., a mother of only one child from Maribojoc, Bohol.

She would like to ask for a loan of Php 14,000 from CEVI, a Kiva partner. She will use the loan to purchase additional ingredients for her food business. The loan will help improve her business even more by allowing her to sell more foods.

CEVI provides financial services to the poor in the form of loans, training and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her food business

loans.name: Henry

texts.en: M. Henry is a 50-year-old married man with ten children. He has been operating his business since 2005. He operates a shop located at Elgin Street dealing with first-hand clothes. He is using the loan to purchase more clothes for both men and women such as trousers, shirts, t-shirts, skirts, dresses, and party wear in hopes of attracting more customers, hence expanding his business and earning more profits. His future hope is to obtain a bigger boutique to capture more customers.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for his shop.

loans.name: Alberta

texts.en: Alberta T. sells clothing at Abura. Alberta has received junior high school education.  She has 5 dependents. Alberta has been selling clothing since 2004. She is responsible for paying housekeeping expenses. Her loan will be used to buy more clothing for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save and also reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothing for resale.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria A. sells clothing at Abura. Victoria has received a junior high school education.  She is married and has 4 dependents. Her husband is a commercial driver. Victoria has been selling clothing since 2001. She is responsible for paying the housekeeping expenses.  Her loan will be used to buy more clothing for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest in her business to increase her capital and profit.

loans.use: To buy more clothing for resale.

loans.name: Yuryi

texts.en:
Yuryi owns a small business selling retail items in one of the local market in Zaporozhye. He owns three vending locations and sells electric light bulbs, extension cords, lighters, etc. Yuryi is married. and his wife Marina is helping him run their family business. 

Yuryi has been in the trade for five years and presently has about 20,000 Grivnyas in inventory. His monthly profit is about 5,000 Grivnyas. This time Yuryi is seeking a loan of 9,700 Grivnyas to stock his new vending location with merchandise.

loans.use: To stock his new vending facility with merchandise

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en: Mary Jane L. is from the village of Puntod. She is 33 years old and is married. Mary Jane owns and operates a business selling seafood products such as fish and shrimp in the local community. Mary Jane has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Mary Jane joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Mary Jane is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her fourth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en: Cynthia G. is married and has 2 children. Cynthia has received education through senior high school.  Her husband is a driver and Cynthia is a trader who has been selling liquid soap for two years. She is responsible for paying the housekeeping expenses. Her loan will be used to buy more liquid soaps to re-sell.  She hopes to use the new profits to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To buy more liquid soap to re-sell.

loans.name: Ibrohim

texts.ru: Иброхим мужчина  в возрасте 43 лет , отец троих детей. Он проживает в районе Уткансой, вблизи горных окраинах. В своём районе он работает врачом в центре здоровья своего посёлка. Иброхим  имеет большой вес в своём районе, его все уважают. Он по специальности врач терапевт, но из-за не хватки его заработной платы на жизнь, он занимается  откормом и продажей скота. С этого бизнеса он имеет хороший доход. Поэтому для увеличения своего скота он хочет получить кредит.
texts.en:
Ibrohim is a 43 year old man, the father of three children. He lives in the Utkansoi district, near the outskirts of the mountains. He works in the district as a doctor at his town's health center. He has great leverage in the district; everyone respects him. He is a doctor (general practitioner) by training, but because his salary is inadequate to live on he also raises and sells livestock. The business earns a good income. He would like to take out a loan to obtain more animals.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising and selling livestock

loans.name: Isidra

texts.en: Isidra B. sells fish. She is 43 years old and has four children. She has been trading fish since she got married to her husband, Mamerto B., who is a fisherman. Aside from their catch, they buy fish from other fisherman and sell it to the village with additional mark-up. She would like to ask for a loan of Php 12,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase fishing materials and fish to sell. The loan will help her grow her fish business even more. CEVI provides financial services to the poor. It offers not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase gear for fishing and fish to sell

loans.name: Nzovwe 1 E Group

texts.en: Sophia has been a food seller in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya. She belongs to Nzovwe 1 E group. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.  She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items to add her current stock and improve her business.  She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.  Sophia is 30 years-old, married, and has two children ages 10 and 5.  She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Stella, who has her own shop in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more food items to add her current stock.

loans.name: Adiza

texts.en: Adiza A. is married and has 3 dependents. She has received schooling through junior high.  Adiza sells beans and maize which she has done since 2006.  Her husband is a shoemaker. Adiza uses her income to pay for the housekeeping expenses. Adiza will use the loan to purchase sacks of maize for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Adiza plans to reinvest in the business and use the rest for savings.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of maize for resale.

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina G. is from the village of Unidos. She is 36 years-old. Gina is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Gina owns and operates a business selling bedding and bedding supplies to tourists and local community members. Gina has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

Gina joined PMPC in 2007 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gina has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC of 15,000 PHP which was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Gina is now requesting her 8th loan from PMPC in the amount of 20,000 PHP which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia N. is married and has 3 dependents. She has received schooling through junior high.  Cecilia sells charcoal at Abura, which she has done since 2004. Her husband is a security guard. Cecilia uses her income to pay for school fees. Cecilia will use the loan to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Cecilia plans to save for the future and also pay the water bill and other domestic bills.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Hasana

texts.en: Hasana L. sells hair cream and weavon as a hairdresser who owns a beauty salon at Abura. Hasana has received a junior high school education. She is single.  Hasana has been a hairdresser selling cream and weavon since 2007. She is responsible for paying the light bill, water bill and other utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more creams, weavon and other hairdressing products. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest.

loans.use: To buy more creams, weavon and other hairdressing products.

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard Kyeyunga is 35 years old and married with two children. He operates a business at Kijjabwemi Masaka town council and has had his business since 2006.

He will use this loan to purchase retail items to sell, such as sugar, biscuits, cooking oil, rice, soap, dry cells, books, and drinks. His hope for the future is to work hard and expand his business to earn extra daily income.

loans.use: To purchase retail shop items to sell.

loans.name: Murodboy

texts.ru: Муродбой кредитор в Микроинвесте с  2008 года. Он  получает займ на расширение бизнеса животноводства. Сам Муродбой работает разнорабочим на дому у людей. Ежедневный заработок он тратит на покупку продуктов семьи. Его бизнес развернулся вдвое, у него сейчас 20 баранов и 15 коз. Муродбой хочет получить повторный кредит на закуп корма скота  и покупки одной большой коровы, которая будет давать молоко. Муродбой благодарен инвесторам за доверие и понимание, потому что у него улучшилась проживание семьи и увеличился доход с бизнеса животноводства.
texts.en:
Murodboy has been a MicroInvest client since 2008. He is getting a loan to expand his livestock business. Murodboy works as a laborer at a people’s home. He spends his salary on purchasing food for his family. His business has doubled. He now has 20 sheep and 15 goats. Murodboy would like to get a second loan to purchase feed for the livestock and to purchase one big cow which will produce milk. Murodboy is grateful to the investors for their trust and understanding, because his family’s living conditions have improved and the income from his livestock business has increased.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Feed and a cow

loans.name: Joana

texts.en:
Joana A. is married and has four dependents. She completed school through junior high and sells plastic rubbers, which she has done for two years. Her husband is a trader. Joana uses her income to pay for housekeeping expenses.

Joana will use this loan to purchase rubbers to resell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Joana plans to reinvest in her business and pay her water and light bills.

loans.use: To purchase rubbers to resell.

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
Adelaida D. is from the village of Calaca-an. She is 49 years old and married with four school-age children. To make a living, Adelaida runs a general store selling food in the local community. She has had her business for over six years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2000, Adelaida joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP. She used the previous loan to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Adelaida is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 17th PMPC loan. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support her immediate family members.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Ruffa

texts.en:
"I am a fish vendor in our village. My husband and I have been selling fish since the start of our marriage. Our income has done many things, especially in providing for the needs of our family. Fish help us pay the school tuition of our grandchildren," says Rufa V., a 66-year-old entrepreneur from Maribojoc, Bohol. She is requesting a loan of Php 9,000 from CEVI to purchase more fish to sell. The loan will help grow her business to increase their income.

CEVI helps small business grow, providing not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase fish to sell.

loans.name: Yvonne

texts.en:
Greetings from Yvonne T.. She is a 33 year old Rwandan entrepreneur. She is single however she has three dependents who are 18, 16, and 10 years old. She lives in the Jali sector of the Gasabo district of Kigali, the capital of Rwanda.

Yvonne does her business in Jali sector. She owns a restaurant that feeds many people in the neighborhood. She starts working at 6:00 a.m and finishes at 8:00 p.m and employs four workers.

She is requesting her first loan for 500,000 Rwf from Vision Finance Company. She earns $440 in monthly profit and hopes to increase her profit after this loan. She will use this loan to expand her restaurant. With increased profits, she will continue to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her restaurant.

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en:
Pacita I. is from the village of Sibula. She is 40 years old and married with three school-age children. To make a living, Pacita runs a general store selling daily use products like shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. She has had her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Pacita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Pacita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP, which she used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. She is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP to use as working capital and purchase additional inventory. This will be her second PMPC loan. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as working capital and to purchase additional inventory.

loans.name: Maya

texts.en:
Maya is a market entrepreneur from Tarascha, Belaya Tserkov region, Ukraine. She runs four vending locations selling groceries, veggies and fruit in one of the local markets. The inventory she has for sale is of very good quality and selection. Maya is respectful and patient with all of her customers and this attracts people and brings them back to buy groceries again. Currently, she has about 20,000 invested in her business as turnover capital. Her monthly net profit is about 5,300 Grivnyas. Maya has 3 hired employees to work for her. 

High inflation rates are affecting businesses in Ukraine. Maya wants to keep her business sustainable and has requested a loan of 6,000 Grivnyas to increase her wholesale inventory. One of her plans for the future is to generate sufficient profit to help her daughter open a beauty center in their home town. Maya doesn’t have anyone to rely on as her husband died in a car crash 9 months ago. We believe that this current loan will enhance the potential of her business and help Maya reach all her aspirations.

loans.use: To buy merchandise for wholesale

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma G. is from the village of Sibula. She is 39 years old, married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Vilma owns & operates a business in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Vilma has been engaged in her business since 1991 and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month.

In 2004, Vilma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Vilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC which was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Vilma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used in the same manner. This will be the 10th loan taken out by Vilma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Bonifacia

texts.en:
Bonifacia G., 53 years old, is from the village of Sibula. Bonifacia is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Bonifacia owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Bonifacia has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2004, Bonifacia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services. Her goal was to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Bonifacia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC.

Bonifacia is requesting a new loan in the amount of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and gain working capital. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Bonifacia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and gain working capital

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia B. sells Bread and Flour at Abura. Felicia has received education through senior high school. Felicia has been selling Bread and Flour since 1999. She is responsible for paying housekeeping expenses and other financial responsibilities.  Her loan will be used for reinvestment, savings and the purchase of more bread and flour for resale. She intends to expand her business and also to increase her capital and profits. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest to expand her business.

loans.use: Business capital, including the purchase of bread and flour

loans.name: Yoro

texts.fr: yoro N. est un jeune commerçant né en 1979 à diama thierry ;il est marié et est père d'un enfant;il habite au quartier cité senghor de thies et y gère une boutique;avec le pret qu'il sollicite il veut renforcer son stock de marchandises;
texts.en:
Yoro N. is a young businessman, born in 1979 in Diama Thierry. He is married and the father of one child. He lives in the Cité Senghor neighborhood of Thies and has a shop there. With the loan, he wants to bolster the inventory of his little shop.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: adding to his inventory

loans.name: Rolita

texts.en:
Rolita T. is from the village of Sibula. She is 42 years old. Rolita is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Rolita owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising goats for sale. Rolita has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine Pesos (about US $63) a month from these activities.

In 2008, Rolita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rolita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 pesos which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Rolita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en:
Benjamin P. is from the town of Lopez Jaena. He is 56 years old. Benjamin is married and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Benjamin owns & operates a business venture in the food sector operating a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from harvesting & selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Benjamin has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine Pesos (about US $42) a month from these activities.

In 2008, Benjamin joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Benjamin has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 pesos from PMPC. Benjamin is requesting a new loan of 10,000 pesos which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Benjamin from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria B. is from the village of Sibula. She is 35 years old. Maria is married and has 4 infant-aged children. To make a living, Maria owns & operates a business making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Maria is just starting this business.

In 2008, Maria joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. Maria is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Maria from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: With passion and love of cooking, that is Mrs. Elizabeth L., 30 years old of Migcanaway, Tangub City. She is married and blessed with one child. She is presently engaged in an eatery business located at the city Food Court. Her husband is a casual government employee of Tangub City Hall. Mrs. L. is the one who cooks the foods and at the same time serves their loyal customers who are the City Hall employees, Teachers, Private employees and even students of the city. They also serve snacks and accept catering services. With the help of their parents, they were able to establish this business with an initial capital of only PHP5,000.00. As a coop member, she has already availed multiple cycle of loans. Now, she is applying for the amount of PHP12,000.00 under the Regular loan program to add to her capital in her existing eatery business. Her dream and aspiration in life is to give her child a better future. For the business, she is hoping that someday she can avail a car loan to be used in the business and for family occasions. She is also thankful to PAGLAUM MPC for the savings education she learned from us and for the Program and Services.

loans.use: Additional capital for their eatery business

loans.name: Enatha

texts.en:
Greetings from M. Enatha, a 22 year-old Rwandan entrepreneur. She is single and she lives in Jali sector, Gasabo district of Kigali city, the capital of Rwanda.

This entrepreneur does her business in Jali sector, one of the rural neighborhoods of Kigali city. She owns a retail shop in which she sells cassava bread, beans and other different stuff. She started this business in the year 2004, and she is requesting her first loan of 500,000 Rwf from Vision Finance Company. With this loan she will buy more products for her shop and the increased profits will be reinvested in the same business. She starts her daily business at 7:00 a.m. and closes at 10:00 p.m.

Enatha earns a monthly profit of approximately $235 and she has one worker who helps her run this business.

loans.use: To buy more products

loans.name: Carolino

texts.en:
Mr. Carolino R. is fifty years old and married with six children. He lives in Labuyo, Tangub City. Four of his children are married with their own families and the other two are dependents attending school. 

Carolino has a chemical wholesale and repackaging business – he works with hypochloric acid and chlorine. His wife assists in repackaging. They started the business with an initial capital of just $17. They have recently started another line of business selling garlic and onions. They have many loyal customers and friends, and their distribution area is expanding. 

Carolino was interested in joining the Kiva Partner, PAGLAUM MPC, for more than just access to loans – he also values the motivation to save that they inspire in their members.  He is applying for a loan in order to add to his capital for both of his businesses. He hopes to send his children to college and renovate his house in the future.

loans.use: Additional capital for both businesses

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort A. sells frozen fish and meat in Abura. Comfort has been educated through junior high school.  She is married and has three children. Comfort has been selling fish and meat for ten years. She is responsible for feeding and clothing her family. Her loan will be used to buy fish and meat, store them in a freezer and then resell. She intends to reinvest the profits into her business.

loans.use: To buy more fish and meat to sell.

loans.name: Salla

texts.fr: SALLA F. est née le 16 fevrier 1970 à thies :elle habite au quartier hersent en face du poste de santé ;depuis quelques années elle fait du commerce d'habits de femmes ;elle achète de la matière première qu'elle donne au tailleur qui lui fait la confection;c'est pour augmenter sa marge bénéficiaire qu'elle demande un nouveau pret ;
texts.en:
Salla F. was born on February 16, 1970 in Thies. She lives in the Hersent neighborhood opposite the dispensary. For several years, she has been selling women's clothing. She buys materials that she gives to a tailor who makes up the clothing for her. She is requesting this new loan to increase her profit.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sale of ready-to-wear

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica P. is from the village of Calaca-an. She is fifty years old and married with two grown children. To make a living, Jessica owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling health and medicinal products in the local community. Jessica has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $45 a month for these activities.

In 2004, Jessica joined the Kiva partner, PMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Jessica has successfully repaid previous loans from PMPC. Jessica is requesting a new loan which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her seventh loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Henry's Group

texts.en:
N. Henry is the leader of Namukozi Suubi group in Mityana. He is a hard working man and married with 4 children 3 of whom are in school. Henry is a farmer with matooke, cassava, sweet potatoes and maize plantations for home consumption and for sale as well as being a poultry farmer with 100 broilers and 300 layers. His layers give him between 8 – 10 trays of eggs every day while the broilers are for meat and sold off after every 2 months.

This is a development that has taken him a long time to realize, and not until he was able to join his lending group and was given the idea. He now sees a change in his life, family, and business since every one is happy now. He sells his eggs in Mityana town and Kampala where the market is big. Henry needs a loan to help with buying more feed for his chicks and hiring manpower on his farm.

loans.use: Chicken feed and payroll

loans.name: Hernamae

texts.en:
Ms. Hernamae G., 21 years old and single, is a resident of P1 Pangabuan, Tangub City. A micro-entrepreneur who currently engages in a refreshment and sari-sari store business. Her parents helped her in establishing this business. She was allowed to use their empty warehouse and converted it to a refreshment and sari-sari Store. Her first customers were relatives, neighbors and friends.

Now her business is still growing and stable. She added more groceries to her Sari-sari Store. Now she is applying for a loan of 25,000.00 Philippine Pesos as her 1st loan under the regular loan program. She believes that PAGLAUM MPC will help her a lot, especially in improving her business (not only for adding capital but also for expansion, beautification and renovation in the future).

loans.use: Additional capital for her refreshment and sari-sari store

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en: Hannah A., educated to the junior high level, has been selling milk, milo, nido, sugar and other provision in Akotokyri since 2007. Single with no dependants, she is responsible for paying utility bills, taxes, and the house rent. Hannah’s loan will be used to purchase more Milo, nido, milk, sugar and other provisions for re-sale, and she hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest in the business.

loans.use: To purchase more Milo, nido, milk, sugar and other provisions for re-sale.

loans.name: Ndeye Coumba

texts.fr: NDEYE COUMBA F. est une femme mariée qui habite au quartier cité senghor de thiès et a cinq enfants en charge;elle fait du petit commerce de fruits de saison pour subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants;elle a eu à bénéficier d'un pret avec kiva qu'elle a remboursé sans difficultés;elle sollicite un nouveau pret pour renforcer son fonds de roulement
texts.en:
Ndeye Coumba F. is a married woman who lives in the Cité Senghor neighborhood of Thiès and is raising 5 children. She is a petty trader selling seasonal fruit to support her children. She has received one loan through Kiva that she reimbursed without difficulty. She is asking for another loan to bolster her working capital.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sale of seasonal fruit

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort T. is married and has 3 children. She has not received a formal education. Comfort sells charcoal in Akotokyri, which she has done since 2001. Comfort uses her income to pay for utility bills. Comfort will use the loan to buy charcoal in larger quantities to expand the business in support of the family. With the new profits from her expanded business, Comfort plans to pay the children's school fees for a higher educational level.

loans.use: To buy charcoal in bulk for resale

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Thirty-five years old and married, Emily C. is from Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines where she operates a sari sari store. She joined PAGLAUM’s microfinance program last July in order to help her husband, and within the period of her membership she has demonstrated excellent performance in terms of loan repayments.

Emily is requesting the loan amount of Php 9,000.00 to buy additional stock such as laundry items, seasonings, goodies, toiletries, drinks and other household items. She hopes to enrich their way of life and expand the business.

loans.use: Additional capital for sari-sari store

loans.name: Isabel

texts.en:
Mrs. Isabel A. is 46 years old, married and lives at Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She joined Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative last March 2005, having faith in true service and assistance to needy people. Determination and hard work are what Mrs. A. believes in.

The poverty in which Isabel and her family live urges her to do her part in improving their lives. She is requesting a loan from Paglaum MPC in order to have additional capital for her sari-sari store. The couple’s aspiration is to have a concrete store and house someday and be able to send their children to school to obtain college educations and a good quality of life.

loans.use: Additional capital for sari-sari store

loans.name: Vasile

texts.en:
This is C. Vasile and he is in agricultural business for many years, he grows vegetables bur only in greenhouses not in the field.

Through the help of Microinvest he was supported to create economic opportunities for himself. In 2005 Vasile found out about an agricultural project in which a small group of middle mans purchase vegetables from Moldova, grind and package it for sale on Romanian domestic market. Vasile is informed about the proceeds from these sales and make the decisions within the household about how that money is spent. 

In 2005 he did not have enough financial resources to start growing vegetables, but now after he borrowed a loan from Microinvest he can reach his aim.

loans.use: Starting business

loans.name: Bombe

texts.fr: madame bombe S. est une vieille dame qui vit au quartier cité senghor de thiès ;elle a  ouvert une cantine depuis plusieurs années pour aider son mari dans l'entretien de sa famille; elle vend des oeufs ;des fruits et des produits divers près de l'hopital régional de thiès;
texts.en:
Mrs. Bombe S. is an older lady who lives in the Cité Senghor neighborhood of Thiès. She has had a little store for several years to help her husband support the family. She sells eggs, fruit, and various other products near the regional hospital in Thiès.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sale of various products

loans.name: Aurelia

texts.en:
Mrs. Aurelia M., 69 years old, is married and lives at Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She has one child who is married already. She spend her life with her husband. She is a member of PAGLAUM since last February 2006 and now she is applying for a loan of 5,000.00 pesos to buy additional stock, such as laundry items, seasonings, goodies, toiletries and other household items for her sari-sari (convenience) store.

Mrs. M. is able to manage this business successfully; in fact, it covers her daily consumption needs and she is able to save money for the future.

loans.use: Additional capital for sari-sari store.

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda A. is a resident of Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She became a member of Paglaum MPC in July 2008, and she is requesting a loan amounting to 5,000 pesos to purchase fertilizer and pesticides for farming.

Imelda is also thankful to Paglaum micro-finance for their programs and services that help the poor people and encourages them to work hard for their future. She wishes to have a better living in the future and to give her children a good future.

loans.use: To purchase corn fertilizer and pesticides.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary O. sells hair products including shampoos, hair creams and other hair products at Akotokyir. She is a hairdresser who owns a beauty salon. Mary has received education through junior high. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a mechanic with a small income which cannot support the family. Mary has been selling hair products for 10 years. She is responsible for paying utilities and taxes.

Mary's loan will be used to buy more hair creams and shampoo for re-sale and also to improve the services she renders to her customers. She hopes to use the profits from her business to re-invest into the business, pay the children’s school fees and any other things in support of the children.

loans.use: To buy more hair creams and shampoo and to improve the services she renders to her customers.

loans.name: Patience

texts.en:
Patience O. sells milk, soft drinks and other provisions in Akotokyri, a business she has had since 1993. Patience has received junior high education. She is married and has no children. Her husband is a porter whose income is too low to support the family, while Patience is responsible for paying utility bills.

Patience will use this loan to buy more goods for business expansion. She hopes to use the profits to re-invest into the business.

loans.use: To buy more goods for business expansion.

loans.name: Femmes Commerçantes N° 14 Group

texts.fr: coumba,fatou ,diarètou,awa et thillo sont un groupe de cinq femmes dynamiques qui mènent des activités génératrices de revenu au marché grand thies;elles vendent des produits diversifiés dont les légumes,le poisson,la salade et les fruits de mer et maitrisent bien leur domaine d'activité;elles ont ouvert un compte à la mutuelle et veulent contracter un pret pour augmenter leur fonds de roulement
texts.en:
Coumba, Fatou, Diarètou, Awa, et Thillo make up a group of 5 energetic women who have businesses in the Grand Thies market. They sell various products, among others vegetables, fish, lettuce, and seafood, and they are very good at managing their businesses. They have joined our institution and would like to take out a loan to use to bolster their working capital.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sale of various products

loans.name: Mihail

texts.en:
Microinvest strives to increase farmers' productivity by helping them obtain quality seeds, introducing them to small-scale irrigation and other farm technologies, and encouraging small, agriculture-based businesses that generate income. With support from Microinvest, Mihail has faced many difficulties in his life to build a viable agricultural business and provide a future for his wife and two children.

Mihail is taking a loan from Microinvest for the purchasing of vegetable seeds, small farm tools and training. He also has developed a small-scale irrigation system, which diverts water from a stream and runs it into canals. Mihail now farms an acre of irrigated land and produces tomatoes and peppers.

Mihail thanks Microinvest for trust and financial support.

loans.use: To purchase vegetable seeds, small farm tools and training.

loans.name: Ayuru

texts.en:
Ayuru M. sells beer at the bar and is requesting a loan to purchase more crates of beer to sell. She is 30 years old and married to a cattle keeper. Ayuru has two children who are attending school at Juba Girls' secondary school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a bar as a selling point.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services. These are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort A. is married and has five dependents. She has not received any formal education. Comfort operates a small chop bar and cooks local banku (fermented maize or cassava tubers cooked and served with soup or stew) and akplee in Akotokyri, which she has done since 2000. Her husband is a police officer in the Ghana Police Services whose income is too low. Comfort uses her income to pay for utilities in support of the family. Comfort will use the loan to buy more foodstuffs to cook and resell. Comfort plans to reinvest the new profits from her expanded business into the business.

loans.use: Comfort will use the loan to buy more foodstuffs to cook and resell

loans.name: Creciendo Juntas Group

texts.es:
El contacto para el inicio del presente comité fue la señora,Lucia P. quien invito y organizo a sus amigas para formar parte del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras.

La sra. Marta Ines C. se dedica a la venta de prendas variadas en general, invirtio el dinero en la compra de prendas en general de esa manera ofrecer mayor variadad a sus clientes. 

La sra. Mirtha Rosa M.  se dedica a la venta de articulos de merseria, invirtio el dinero en la compra de esas mercaderias al por mayor y venderlos obteniendo asi mayor ingreso, y variedad para su clientela.

La sra. Maria Alcira B. se dedica a la venta de joyas de plata, invirtio el dinero en la compra de plateria de esa manera surtir su mercaderia y ofrecer mayor variedad a sus clientes.

La sra. Maria Fabiola G. se dedica a la venta aceites, carne, yerba y bebidas invirtio el dinero en la compra de esas mercaderias logrando ofrecer mayor variedad a sus clientes.

La sra. Nydia Concepcion B. se dedica a la ventra de comestible, invirtio el dinero en la compra de mercaderias para la elaboracion de los comestibles logrando ofrecer variedad y buenos precios a sus clientes.

La sra. Saturnina R. se dedica a la venta de prendas en generla, invirtio el dinero en la compra de  esas mercederias al por mayor ofreciendo buena calidad y variedad de prendas a su
 clientela.

La sra. Nilda Raquel C. es costurera,  invirtio el dinero en la compra de materiales para su trabajo,  logrando de esa manera poder producir con mas eficazcia.

La sra. Maxima E. tiene una despensa, invirtio el dinero en la compra de mercaderias en general, ofreciendo de esa manera gran variedad de mercaderias a su clientela.

La sra. Casiana T. se dedica a la venta de comestibles bebidas en general, invirtrio el dinero en la compra de bebidas y ingredientes para la elaboracion de los comestibles, pudiendo ofrecer mayor variedad de comestibles a sus clientes y  aumentar su ingreso.

La sra. Maria Ignacia  C. se dedica a la venta de frutas,  invirtio el dinero en la compra de frutas al por mayor, logrando obtener mayor variedas de frutas para sus clientes.

La sra. Esmelda Barreto se dedideca a la  venta de bebidas, invirtio el dinero en la compra de bebidas en general pudiendo ofrecer buena variedad de bebidas a su clientela.

La sra. Rita B. Quiñonez se dedica a la venta de comestible, invirtio el dinero en la compra de mercaderia para la elaboracion de los comestibles logrando buena variedad de comestible para sus clientes.

La sra. Maria Dolores R. de se dedica a la venta de prendas invirtio el dinero en la compra de prendas en general ofreciendo  calidad y variedad de prendas a su clientela.

La sra. Lucia Angelica P. se dedica a la venta de medicamentos farmaceuticos, invirtio el dinero en la compra de    esos productos, ofreciendo buena variedad de medicamentos a sus clientes.

La sra. Mirta Graciela P. se dedica a la venta de prendas variadas, invirtio el  dinero en la compra de prendas en general logrando buena variedad para ofrecer a sus clientes.

 La sra. Marisol O.  tiene una cantina, invirtio el dinero en la compra de golisinas, gaseosas y insumo para la elaboracion de comestibles logrando ofrecer buena variedad a su clientela.

La sra.Cinthia B. se dedica a la venta de bebidas, invirtio el dinero en la compra de bebidas en general, logrando ofrecer buena variedad de bebidasd a sus clientes.
texts.en:
The initial contact for this group was Lucia P.. She invited and organized her friends to form part of the program called Committee of Enterprising Women. Marta Ines C. sells various articles of clothing. She used the money to buy general articles of clothing to be able to provide her customers with more variety. Mirtha Rosa M. sells notions. She used the money to buy these notions wholesale. She then sells them and gets a greater income while giving her customers variety. Maria Alcira B. sells silver jewelry. She used the money to buy silver items to stock her merchandise and offer greater variety to her customers. Maria Fabiola G. sells oils, meat, herbs, and drinks. She used her money to buy this merchandise, which allows her to offer greater variety to her customers. Nydia Concepcion B. sells food. She used the money to buy merchandise for making the food. She is able to offer variety and good prices to her customers. Saturnina R. sells general articles of clothing. She used the money to buy this merchandise wholesale. She offers good quality and a variety of articles of clothing to her customers. Nilda Raquel C. is a seamstress. She used the money to buy materials for her work. This way she is able to improve her production. Maxima E. has a store. She used the money to buy general merchandise. She offers a great variety of merchandise to her customers. Casiana T. sells general food and drinks. She used the money to buy drinks and ingredients for making the food. She is able to offer a greater variety of food to her customers and increase her income. Maria Ignacia C. sells fruit. She used her money to buy wholesale fruit. She is able to get a greater variety of fruits for her customers. Esmelda Barreto sells drinks. She used her money to buy general drinks. She is able to offer a greater variety of drinks to her customers. Rita B. Quiñónez sells food. She used her money to buy merchandise to makerthe food. She is able to have a greater variety of food for her customers. Maria Dolores R. sells articles of clothing. She used her money to buy general items of clothing. She offers quality and a variety of clothes to her customers. Lucia Angelica P. sells pharmaceuticals. She used her money to buy these products and offer a good variety of medicines to her customers. Mirta Graciela P. sells various articles of clothing. She used her money to buy general clothing. She offers a good variety to her customers. Marisol O. has a food stand. She used her money to buy sweets, soft drinks, and ingredients to make food. She offers a good variety to her customers. Cinthia B. sells drinks. She used her money to buy general drinks. She offers a good variety of drinks to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy general articles of clothing, silver jewelry, supplies to make food(eggs, bread, vegetables, etc.) General drink sales, fruit, dairy products, canned goods, herbs, oil, sugar

loans.name: María Del Carmen

texts.en: Mrs María del Carmen B. was born in Luque and has two young children. She has been married to Valentín Lucena Martínez, a dispatcher in the Customs office in Asunción, for over ten years. For the last eight years she has worked making, among other things, dress garments and uniforms. The credit that Kiva partner, Fundación Paraguaya, has given María has been used to purchase fabrics and accessories to make garments, and also for some home refurbishments.

loans.use: To purchase fabric and accessories for dressmaking

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba H. is married and has three children. She has not received any formal education. Aba's husband is a trader, but his income is too small to care for the family. Since 2003 Aba has operated a small chop bar in Abura, where she cooks rice and stew. She uses her earnings to pay her children's school fees and to buy food for the family. Aba will use her loan to buy rice, oil, tomatoes and other ingredients so that she can increase the amount of food she cooks and sells. With the new profits from her expanded trade, Aba plans to both reinvest in her business and save in the Susu savings scheme.

loans.use: To buy rice, oil, tomatoes and other ingredients

loans.name: Mujeres Activas Group

texts.en:
The funds obtained by this group are invested in small businesses owned by each one of its members. All of the group members invest according to the needs that they have in their business ventures. The women, dedicated to their sales, invest in the purchase of goods such as fruits, vegetables, rice, coal, etc.     

Graciela M. B. – sale of foodstuffs 
Melody Caballero – sale of general goods 
Sonia A. – sale of vegetables 
María O. – sale of fruits 
Elizabeth N. – domestic employment
Felicita B.  – small convenience store 
Rosa V. – small grocery store
Maria A. – small grocery store
Maria E. – fruit sales 
Liz C. – fruit sales 
Maria L.  – coal sales 
Mercedes G. – convenience store 
Iluminada L. – fruit sales 
Silvia O. – sale of meats and sausages 
Domiciana A. – sale of coal and meats

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs to sell
