loans.name: Naser Group

texts.en:
The group name is N.; it is made of three ladies, who are living in the region of the Aley, Mount Lebanon. 

- Klourya is a 22-year-old woman. She has been selling accessories for five years and has requested a loan of $300 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise like makeup and other types of accessories. This is the first time that she has requested a loan.

Klourya is special in her work because she knows how to treat her clients and sells a nice variety of products. Her clients are people from her region, as well as accessories shops. When she first started her business, she didn’t face difficulties. She decided on her business because she has good networking. In the future, she plans on expanding her work. 

- Nazha is a 49-year-old married woman with three children who has been producing handicrafts for over ten years. She requested a loan of $300 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase materials like thread and accessories for her work. This is the first time that she has requested a loan.

Nazha is special in her work because of she likes what she does and she does it well. Her clients are her friends, neighbors and others. When she first started her business, she didn’t face difficulties. In the future, she plans on improving her work.

- Zienah is a 23-year-old woman. She has been doing handicrafts for two years making, for example, design boxes, bags and lots more. She requested a loan of $300 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase thread for her work. This is the first time that she has requested a loan.

Zienah is special in her work because of her good taste. Her clients can be anybody from her region. In the future, she plans on improving her work.

loans.use: To purchase items for their businesses

loans.name: Kuña Katupyry Group

texts.en:
This group is from the district of San Pedro Viviendas and was suggested by a participant of the Foundation.  All of the women do their own productive activities: small grocery store, food sales, clothing sales, lingerie sales, sale of foodstuffs, running of a telephone booth and a convenience store.  The amount received by each woman varies between 300,000 and 2,000,000 Gs.  All of the women will invest their money in activities that they are already doing. 

1.	Aida L. D. S.- Sale of foodstuffs 
2.	Bella L. D. A.- Sale of clothing 
3.	Concepción A. G.- Sale of vegetables
4.	Analía M. B.- Sale of foodstuffs 
5.	Sonia G. O.- Small grocery store
6.	Salustiana R.- Sale of clothing
7.	Silvana A. A.- Sale of lingerie. 
8.	Ramona O. D. D.- Kiosk/drink stand 
9.	Blanca Dora D.- Telephone booth. 
10.	Ramona Mabel L. R.- Rotisserie
11.	Nancy Beatríz P.- Sale of lingerie 
12.	Gloria G. L.- Sale of clothing 
13.	Mónica Andrea L.- Cook

15.	Myrian Graciela D.- Perfume store 
16.	Cristina B. A. – Sale of food 
17.  Analía Evelín D. - Sale of clothes

loans.use: The purchase of foodstuffs

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther D. is single and has no children. She has received schooling through junior high. Esther sells ladies clothing which includes panties, bras, shoes and bags in Abura. She has done this for seven years. Esther uses her income to pay for feeding and clothing herself. Esther will use the loan to buy more ladies wear to resell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Esther plans to re-invest and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more ladies wear to resell.

loans.name: Restaurador Group

texts.en:
The Restaurador group was started thanks to Ramona Romero, who is a leader of the El Bosque Restaurador neighborhood, where the group is located.  Ramona contacted Fundacion Paraguaya and she invited the women of the neighborhood to form an entrepreneurship group.  The group is now in its ninth cycle of the Womens' Entrepreneurship Program at Fundacion Paraguaya. The group is made up of 16 members, each of whom invests her money in different activities.  
 
Mrs. Eustaquia E. has a small grocery store and she invests her money in the purchase of merchandise to re-stock her business.  

Mrs. Benedicta O. works selling vegetables and invests her money in the purchase of vegetables for the largest profit from her sales. 

Mrs. Johana C. has a small grocery store and invests her money in the purchase of goods to supply and to increase her business. 

Mrs. Blanca M. has a small grocery store and invests her money in the purchase of goods to supply and to increase her business. 

Mrs. Katerine I. works selling trinkets and invests her money in the purchase of these goods to sell outside of the city. 

Mrs. Elizabeth O. works selling ice cream and invests her money in the purchase of ice cream and the maintenence of her freezer. 

Mrs. Mirta I. works selling household goods and invests her money in the purchase of these goods to increase her business. 

Mrs. Matilde O. works buying and selling plastics and invests her money in the purchase of these goods to sell outside of the city. 

Mrs. Emilia R. works selling vegestables and invests her money in the purchase of vegetables for the best profit possible from her sales. 

Mrs. Rosa J. works selling fruits and invests her money in the purchase of fruits for the best profit possible from her sales. 

Mrs. Mirta A. works selling vegetables and invests her money in the purchase of vegetables for the best profit possible from her sales. 

Mrs. Cresencia M. works selling household goods and invests her money in the purchase of these goods to increase her business. 

Mrs. Basalina S. works selling trinkets and invests her money in the purchase of these goods to sell. 

Mrs. Cecilia M. works selling foodstuffs and invests her money in the purchase of these goods for elaboration and selling. 

Mrs. Celia M. has a small grocery store and invests her money in the purchase of goods to supply and to increase her business. 

Mrs. Francisca B. works selling foodstuffs and invests her money in the purchase of these goods for elaboration and selling.

loans.use: To purchase mechandise to re-stock her store

loans.name: Larisa

texts.en: In 2005, Larisa was able to turn a corner in terms of her family’s circumstances due to her new found savings. She purchased a plot of land on the edge of the town of Calarasi, which is a regional capital. There she constructed a house and rented it out to another family for additional income. The following year, she was able to build an iron-roofed house for her family to expand from the thatch-roofed stone hut they had lived in for years. Since then, Larisa's business has grown even more, with a second plot of land and house for rent. Larisa is a self-sufficient farmer and businesswoman. She is able to provide food, clothing, and shelter for her family and education for her children.  This is a long way from where she was when she first received a loan from Microinvest. Now she has decided to take another loan from Microinvest to launch her business. She plans to grow vegetables like potatoes, cucumbers, and eggplants.

loans.use: Grow vegatables

loans.name: Fati

texts.en: Fati U. sells provisions such as Milo, sugar, canned fish, and other good provisions in Abura. Fati has a junior high education. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a driver whose income is too low to support the family. Fati has been selling provisions for four years. She is responsible for feeding the children and clothing the family. Her loan will be used to buy more provisions to sell. She hopes to use the new profits to re-invest in her business.

loans.use: To buy provisions to sell

loans.name: Asociación De Mujeres Emprendedoras Group

texts.en:
This group from the Buena Vista neighborhood was suggested by one of the participants of the Foundation.  All of the women have their own productive activities, such as a small grocery store, cosmetics, dress making, clothing sales, ice cream sales, and toy sales.  The amount of money received by each woman varies between 500,000 and 800,000 PYG.  All of the women invest in activities which they are already involved with. 

1.	Lourdes Elizabeth G. E.- Sale of trinkets 
2.	Mónica Isabel G. R. D.- Small grocery store 
3.	Hermenegilda R.- Clothing sales
4.	María Alicia B. F.- Dressmaker
5.	María Angélica R. R.- Teacher and cosmetics sales 
6.	Zulma L. A.- Teacher and book sales 
7.	Biembenida L.-Toy sales 
8.	Evany Analía P. B.- Trinket sales
9.	Nidia Ester E.- Tailor shop 
10.	Sandra Elizabeth D. O.- Sales of foodstuffs 
11.	Gladys E. D. G.- Food sales  
12.	Liz Analía P. Y.- Towel sales 
13.	Mirta Elizabeth L. – Food sales 
14.	Bernarda F. D. V.- Food sales 
15.    Perla Beatríz O. - Ice cream sales

loans.use: Ice Cream Sales

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es:
Mercedes  esta casada con Darío Fariña, quien se desempeña como taxista, y ellos tienen 2 hijos. El negocio lo tiene en el centro mismo de la ciudad de Caacupé y el servicio de la peluquería lo realiza con 5 peluqueras más.

Mercedes comenta que en la zona hay mucha competencia debido a eso ella desea modernizar al máximo su local y también por que trajo peluqueras de la competencia y estas traen consigo sus propia clientela.
Los préstamos otorgados por la Fundación Paraguaya lo invirtieron en la compra de muebles para su peluquería.

Comenta también que utiliza  todo tipo de estrategias para atraer nuevos clientes, resalta que en todas las temporadas del año ella lanza promociones, para así atraer más  clientes.

Mercedes y  Darío manifiestan su agradecimiento por el apoyo constante que le brinda la Fundación Paraguaya para el fortalecimiento de su microempresa, y a la vez espera contar siempre con la ayuda recibida de la institución.
texts.en:
Mercedes is married to Dario Farina and they have two children. Dario works as a taxi driver. Her salon is located in the center of the city of Caacupe, where there are 5 other beauty salons. Mercedes notes that there is a lot of competition in the area, which is why she wants to modernize her salon as much as possible to attract new clients as well as continue with her regular clients. She uses various strategies to attract new business, including promotions she launches every season. She has invested the loans she has received in furniture for the salon.

Mercedes and Dario are grateful for the ongoing support that Fundacion Paraguaya provides for their small business, and they hope to continue receiving help from the institution.


Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase new furniture for her beauty salon

loans.name: Philomena

texts.en: Philomena D. is married and has three children. She has received schooling through senior-high school. Philomena sells shoes and bags in Abura, which she has done for two years. Her husband works with Ghana Education Services. Philomena uses her income for feeding the children and taking care of other financial needs of the family. Philomena will use the loan to purchase more varieties of bags and shoes to resell. Philomena plans to reinvest the new profits from her expanded business back into her business.

loans.use: To purchase more varieties of bags and shoes to resell

loans.name: Bui Thi

texts.en:
S. Bùi Thị is forty-five years old and married with three grown children. She lives in the town of Ninh Giang.  To make a living, S. owns a business selling rice products in the local community.  She has been engaged in this business for over twenty years and earns approximately $170 a month from these activities.


In 2002, S. joined TYM Fund, a Kiva field partner, to gain access to financial services that enabled her to engage in business activities which would help improve her living situation.  S. has successfully repaid previous loans from TYM Fund.  These previous loans were used to invest in expanding the business.  She is now requesting a new loan that will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the rice products she sells.  This will be her seventh loan from TYM Fund.  S. plans to use the additional revenue generated by this loan to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for rice products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy American rice, sugar, beans, flour, oil, chicken and beef

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en:
N. Nguyễn Thị is fifty-five years old and lives in the town of Ninh Giang.  She is married and has two grown children.  To make a living, N. owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale.  She has been engaged in this business for over twenty years and earns approximately $200 a month from these activities.

In 2002, N. joined the Kiva field partner, TYM Fund, to gain access to financial services that would help improve her living situation by giving her the ability to engage in business activities.  She has successfully repaid previous loans from TYM Fund.  These loans were used to invest in expanding her business.  N. is now requesting a new loan that will be used to purchase breeding livestock.  This will be her seventh loan from TYM Fund.  N. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to continue making improvements in her business.

loans.use: to purchase breeding livestock

loans.name: Dao Thi

texts.en:
Nụ Đào Thị is forty years old and lives in the town of Ninh Giang.  She is married and has three small children.  To make a living, Nụ owns and operates a business selling rice products in the local community.  Nụ has been engaged in this business for over twenty years and earns approximately $170 a month from these activities.

In 2002, Nụ joined the Kiva field partner, TYM Fund, to gain access to financial services that would help improve her living situation by giving her the ability to engage in business activities.  Nụ has successfully repaid previous loans from TYM Fund.  These loans were used to invest in expanding her business.  Nụ is now requesting a new loan that will be used to purchase the raw ingredients she needs to make the rice products she sells.  This will be her seventh loan  from TYM Fund.  Nụ plans to use her profits to continue to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en:
V. Nguyễn Thị is fifty-five years old and lives in the town of Ninh Giang.  She is married and has three grown children.  To make a living, V. owns and operates a business raising cattle for sale.  She has been engaged in this business for over twenty years and earns approximately $230 a month from these activities.

In 2002, V. joined TYM Fund, a Kiva field partner, to gain access to financial services that would help improve her living situation by giving her the ability to engage in business activities.  V. has successfully repaid previous loans from TYM Fund.  These loans were used to expand the shelters for her livestock.  V. is now requesting a new loan that will be used to purchase breeding livestock.  This will be her seventh loan from TYM Fund.  V. plans to use the additional profits generated by this loan to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase breeding livestock.

loans.name: Nguvu Mpya Group

texts.en:
Anjestory Nenjewele, 34 and married with three children aged nine, five and two, has a retail shop business which he started in 2006.  Working from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. daily, he is able to earn a monthly profit of around $90.  This will be Anjestory’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania; his previous loan, since repaid, was used to increase his shop stock. He wants to buy additional items for his store with this new loan.

Anjestorty will share this loan with his group, Nguvu Mpya, which consists of 19 members. These members hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Anjestory is the first from the right, second row.

loans.use: To increase store stock.

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas Group

texts.en:
The group, United Women, was formed through the gathering of several neighbors from the district Ypati from the city of Villa Elisa.  The participants formed a committee in order to apply for a group loan and to satisfy the needs for capital that every one of them had for their respective businesses.  All of the participants of the group depend on their businesses and with time have been growing and improving little by little, thanks to the teamwork and the unity among the participants. 

1	Demetria C. - Coal sales 
2	Ceferina M. - Grocery store  
3	Antonia Lopez - Vegetable sales
4	Ramona C. - Convenience store 
5	Petrona C. - Grocery store 
6	Basilia M. - Cosmetic sales 
7	Elida Benitez - Dressmaker 
8	Ester A. - Handicrafts 
9	Zunilda H. - Ice cream sales 
10	Higinia A. - Recycling 
11	Karina A. M. - Plastics sales 
12	Maria Josefina G. - Cosmetic sales 
13	Sonia E. V. - Dressmaker 
14	Digna G. - General store 
15	Emelda M. - Food sales

loans.use: The credit received from the Paraguay Foundation was invested in the small businesses of each one of the participants.  Each one used the loan for necessities, whether they were raw materials or goods to sell.  For example, the women who invested in small stores bought things like rice, sugar, meats and fruits.  The women who work as dressmakers acquired raw materials such as thread, fabrics, etc.

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.en:
T. Phạm Thị is fifty years old and lives in the town of Gia Lộc.  She is married and has three school-age children.  To make a living, T. owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale.  T. has been engaged in this business for over twenty years and earns approximately $205 a month from these activities.

In 2008, T. joined the Kiva field partner, TYM Fund, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by giving her the ability to engage in business activities.  T. has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund.  This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock.  T. is now requesting a new loan that will be used to expand the shelter for her livestock.  This will be her second loan from TYM Fund.  T. plans to use the profits to continue making improvements to her business.

loans.use: To expand the shelter for her livestock

loans.name: Ho Thi

texts.en:
M. Hồ Thị is a forty years old and lives in the town of Gia Lộc.  She is married and has three school-age children.  To make a living, M. owns and operates a business running a food stall where she sells a variety of products in the local community.  M. has been engaged in this business for over six years and earns approximately $230 a month from these activities.


In 2008, M. joined the Kiva field partner, TYM Fund, to gain access to financial services that would help improve her living situation through engaging in business activities.  M. has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.  M. is now requesting a new loan that will be used to invest in expanding the business.  This will be her second loan from TYM Fund.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Mujeres Trabajadoras De Luque Group

texts.en:
The Mujeres Trabajadoras group was started thanks to the Mujeres Luchadoras group from the Costa S. neighborhood.  One of the members of that group suggested to her sister that she should form a women's group in Luque's 3rd of May neighborhood.  From that suggestion came the creation of the Mujeres Trabajadoras group.  Currently, the women are in their fifth cycle of Fundacion Paraguaya's Women's Entrepreneurship Program.  There are sixteen women in the group, each of whom invests her loans in different activities.  

Mrs. Carmen P. works as a seamstress and invests her money in the purchase of large quantities of fabrics and thread to be used in the creation and sale of her garments.  

Mrs. Jorgelina S. works as a manicurist and invests her money in the purchase of goods for her business.  

Mrs. Mercedes D. works selling fruits and invests her money in the purchase of fruit for the best profit from her sales. 

Mrs. Carmen A. works selling meat delicacies and invests her money in the purchase of meats for the best profit for her business. 

Mrs. Rosa L. works buying and selling hair and is a wig maker.  She invests her money in the purchase of hair to sell outside of the city. 

Mrs. Celsa G. works selling plants and invests her money in the purchase of goods needed to care for the plants. 

Mrs. Myrian L. works as a dressmaker and invests her money in the purchase of fabrics and thread in order to make and sell her garments. 

Mrs. Liliana C. works selling food in a grocery shop and invests money in the purchase of goods and for the displaying and marketing of them to sell. 

Mrs. María S. works as a dressmaker and invests her money in the purchase of fabric and thread for the making and selling of her garments. 

Mrs. Patricia A. works selling clothes and invests her money in the purchase of goods to make the most profit possible from her sales. 

Mrs. María N. works selling clothes and invests her money in the purchase of goods to make the most profit possible from her sales. 

Mrs. Estanislaa N. works selling food in a grocery shop and invests money in the purchase of goods and for the advertising and displaying of them to sell. 

Mrs. Fermina A. works selling meat delicacies and invests her money in the purchase of meats for the best profit for her business. 

Mrs. Mercedes P. works selling clothing and she invests her money in the purchase of various merchandise. 

Mrs. María Dominga I. works selling fruits and invests her money in the purchase of fruit for the best profit from her sales. 

Mrs. Pascuala Ruía N. works selling food in a grocery shop and invests money in the purchase of goods and for the marketing of them to sell.

loans.use: The purchase of carbon, shirts, nail polish, nail polish-remover, cosmetics, fruits, meats, plants, fabrics, threads, shorts, pants, dough for empanadas, breads, sodas, beers, sweets, flour, rice, noodles, sugar, herbs, milk and other things.

loans.name: Vũ Thị

texts.en:
Hà Vũ Thị is a 45 year-old female living in the town of Gia Lộc. She is married and has three school-aged children. To making a living, Hà owns and operates a general store in the retail sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling food and daily-use products. Hà has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 3800000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2008, Hà joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Hà has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund. She used the previous loan to purchase additional products to sell. Hà is now requesting a new loan of 9000000 VND that she will use to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Hoàng Thị

texts.en:
Xuê Hoàng Thị is 40 years old and lives in the town of Gia Lộc. She is married and has three school-age children. To make a living, Xuê raises livestock, primarily chickens. Xuê has been engaged in this business for over seven years and earns approximately 4000000 VND a month.

In 2008, Xuê joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation. Xuê has successfully repaid her previous loan from TYM Fund. She used that loan to purchase breeding livestock. Xuê is now requesting a new loan so she can purchase baby chickens. Xuê plans to use the additional revenue generated by the loan to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy chicks

loans.name: Hồ Thị

texts.en:
L. Hồ Thị is 35 yeas old and lives in the town of Gia Lộc. She is married and has two school-age children.  To make a living, L. owns and operates a restaurant. L. has been engaged in this business for over seven years and earns approximately 4500000 VND a month.

In 2008, L. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services  so she could improve her living situation. L. has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund. She used the previous loan to purchase food and drinks for the restaurant. L. is now requesting a second loan that she will use to expand her business.

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Nguyễn Thị

texts.en:
V. Nguyễn Thị  is 45 years old and lives in the town of Gia Lộc. She is married and has two school-age children.  To making a living, V. owns and operates a clothing business. V. has been engaged in this business for over eight years and earns approximately 4000000 VND a month.

In 2008, V. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services so she could improve her living situation.  V. successfully repaid her previous loan from TYM Fund. She used the loan to increase her working capital and to purchase additional inventory. V. is now requesting a new loan that she will use to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Nicolas

texts.en:
Mr. Nicolas P. is from the city of Carapeguá and currently lives with his wife Aida in the district of Caazapá.

Mr. P. is known throughout the area as a hardworking and enterprising person. He dedicates himself to several commercial activities doing things such as selling milk and automobile lubricants door-to-door.  

Mr. P. is restarting his activities again as he recuperates from the loss of his 13-year-old daughter who died of cancer. Despite several problems in his life, Nicolas keeps fighting and working in order to move forward, and he has demonstrated that he is a man who keeps his promises.  

He will use the loan to buy automobile lubricants and other items to sell.

loans.use: Buy automobile lubricants and other items to sell

loans.name: Herry

texts.en: Herry A. A. is single and has no children. He has received schooling through senior high. Herry has been selling Mobile Phones and their accessories, in Abura, for 2 years. Herry uses his income to pay for feeding himself and for other personal expenses. Herry will use the loan to purchase a variety of more modern mobile phones to resell. With the new profits from his expanded business, Herry plans to re-invest into his business.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of more modern mobile phones to resell.

loans.name: Nuevo Amanecer Group

texts.en:
The committee “The New Dawn” formed with the union of various neighbors from the city Villa Eliza. All of the participants of the committee develop their own independent activities, such as sales. The participants formed a very united group. They are capable of achieving their goals, as well as strengthen their partnership. 
All of the participants in the committee are mothers that dedicate themselves to various activities with the goal of strengthening the household economy and developing a way of sustainable business. 

1	Elsa C. - Ice cream sales 
2	Irma R. - Dressmaker 
3	Maria R. - Detergent sales 
4	Beatriz C. - Manicurist 
5	Marylina A. - Dressmaker 
6	Daniela Benitez - Convenience store 
7	Maria Graciela H. - General store
8	Lucinda R. - Dressmaker 
9	Maria Noemi C. - Fruit sales 
10	Adolfina C. - Coal sales 
11	Nelida V. O. - Beverage sales 
12	Margarita M. - Food sales 
13	Ursulina G. - Coal sales 
14	Luz Maria B. - Food sales 
15	Maria M. - Recycling and plastic sales 
16	Nidia S. - Hardware store 
17	Hermelinda B. - Beverage sales 
18	Adriana G. - Clothing sales 
19	Francisca C. -Clothing sales

loans.use: To invested in the small businesses of each one of the participants. Each participant invests according to the needs of her business. Purchases  such as fruits, vegetables, rice, coal, etc. Dressmakers invest  buying raw materials: threads, fabrics, needles, etc.

loans.name: Mt Mdizunga Group

texts.en:
Joyce A., age 41, is married with four children, ages 20, 17, 14 and 8. She has had a food business since 1990. She works daily from 8am until 12noon. She is able to earn a monthly profit of around $148 

This will be Joyce’s 5th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to buy more food items to sell at Tegeta Primary school. She has repaid the loans successfully.  She hopes for a new loan to buy a stove to start baking cakes and bread. 
 
Joyce will share this loan with her subgroup A, Mt Udizungwa, which totals 6 members. The members hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Joyce is 1st on the left.

loans.use: To buy a stove for baking cakes and bread.

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua A. is married and has 4 dependants. She has received no formal education. Ekua sells charcoal in small quantity in Abura, which she has done for the past 10 years. Her husband is a cleaner whose income is too small to take care of his family. Ekua uses all her income for feeding and clothing the family. Ekua will use the loan to purchase bags on a bit larger quantity of charcoal for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ekua plans to re-invest into the business.

loans.use: To purchase bags of charcoal on a bit larger quantity for resale.

loans.name: Remigio

texts.en:
Mr. Remigio Recalde is from Carapeguá and lives in the Pacheco district, located about 23 km outside of the city. He is married to Mrs. Juanita and they have two children.

Remigio works independently, traveling to and from the cities of Villarica, San Juan Misiones and others, offering his bedspreads to sell.  He currently has 150 clients. He is known, in his community, as a multi-faceted individual who will take advantage of any opportunity that arises.  

The credit applied for is used for the purchase of bedspreads.

loans.use: The purchase of bedspreads for resale.

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en: Leticia A. is married and has 2 children. She has received schooling through Junior High. Leticia has been selling food products such as cassava, plantains, yams and cereals in Abura for the past 14 years. Her husband is a cleaner whose income is too small to take care of the family. Leticia uses all her income for feeding and clothing the entire family. Leticia will use the loan to purchase food products in bulk for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Leticia plans to re-invest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase the food products in bulk for resale.

loans.name: Nuevo Amanecer 1 Group

texts.en:
The funds that this committee has invested have been used for the purchase of primary necessities and are used in their respective businesses. 

1	Clotilde B.	 - Various sales  
2	Dionicia Martinez - Sweets sales  
3	Francisca D. - Clothing sales 
4	Nidia B. -Handicraft sales 
5	Fernanda G. - Dressmakers 
6	Rosa F. - Clothing sales 
7	Liz V. -Small grocery store 
8	Irene S. - Fruit Sales
9	Maria C. - Street vendor 
10	Rosalba G. - Empanada sales 
11	Rosanna G. - Domestic worker 
12	Eustacia G. - Domestic worker 
13	Ilda D. - Lottery sales 
14	Gloria B. - Grocery store
15	Margarita O. - Sales of foodstuffs 
16	Encarnacion V. - Clothing sales 
17	Carmen G. - Clothing sales 
18	Karina C. - Domestic worker

loans.use: Business Capital.

loans.name: Tomaza

texts.en:
Mrs. Tomaza Cáceres is from the city of Carapeguá and lives in the Potrero district, 3 km from downtown. She is a single mother with two children. She dedicates herself to the sale of fine clothing for special occasions and clothing for men.

Mrs. Tomaza has been working in this field for more than 10 years and has a place in which she sells clothes in the middle of the Municipal market, where she has a good clientele.

The credit applied for was used to buy clothes for the new season.

loans.use: The purchase of clothing to sell.

loans.name: Rufina

texts.en:
Mrs. Rufina D. G. is 49 years old and is married to Diosnel Arrúa, who works in construction as a labor contractor. They have two children. The first is 30 years old, a math teacher, and is also enrolled and studying countable sciences. The other son is 15 years old and is enrolled in high school at a local institution.

Mrs. Rufina has had a small grocery store operating out of her house since 1990. She sells common household goods as well as groceries. 
Mrs. Rufina is applying for a loan to buy household items and groceries: mainly sugar, noodles and rice of different brands.  In this way she will make the cost cheaper and earn more profit from the sale of these products.  She will also have a better variety of products to offer her clients, giving them better service.

loans.use: To purchase goods for sale, such as sugar, rice, herbs and different types of noodles.

loans.name: Amy

texts.fr: Amy F. vend des tissus qu’elle importe des pays limitrophes du Sénégal. Elle fait ce travail depuis  plusieurs années .Elle a eu a bénéficié de deux prêts de la caisse pour renforcer son commerce. Les revenus tirés du commerce lui permettent d’aider son mari hôtelier dans l’entretien de la maison surtout des enfants. Avec le prêt qu’il sollicite il veut renforcer son activité en augmentant sa capacité d approvisionnement. Elle habit à Mbour ville côtière située à 70 km de Dakar la capitale du Sénégal. Elle est âgée de 39 ans
texts.en:
Amy F. sells cloth that she imports from countries bordering Senegal. She has been doing this work for several years. She has benefited from two loans from the bank for bolstering her business. The revenues derived from it allow her to help her husband, a hotel keeper, with taking care of the house and especially the children. With the loan she's requesting, Amy wants to bolster her business by augmenting her ability to stock up on merchandise. She lives in Mbour, a coastal city located 70 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal. She is 39 years old.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cloth

loans.name: Las Muñequitas Group

texts.es:
Foto: De izquierda a derecha, María Teresa G. L., Ana Lisbet C. M. y Ángel Lissethe O. M.

El grupo solidario Muñequitas está integrado por doña , María Teresa G. L., Ana Lisbet C. M. y Ángel Lissethe O. M..
Doña   María Teresa es la coordinadora del grupo, se dedica a la venta de ropa ambulante, ofrece ropa usada y nueva, tiene un niño, va la escuela, tiene tres años de dedicarse a esta actividad. Ella va a invertir su financiamiento en comprar encargos que le han hecho sus clientes para el día de la Madre, comprará ropa, perfumes, zapatos, etc.
Ella es casada, su esposo le ayuda con los gastos del hogar, pero ella le gusta tener su negocio para tener su propio ingreso y así comprarse ropa que a ella le gusta. 

La otra integrante es doña Ana Lisbet se dedica a la venta de repostería desde hace dos años, ofrece de forma ambulante y entrega en pulperías, ha crecido en su negocio, con el crédito compró mas variedad y así ha logrado tener más clientes

Doña Ángel Lissete, ella se dedica a la venta de cosméticos en su lugar donde vive, ofrece los productos a los vecinos y demás personas de la comarca.
Expresa que el crédito que obtuvo en Adim lo utilizó en la compra de cosméticos y perfumes que tenía encargados por sus clientes.

El grupo espera siempre ser un grupo puntual, esto les ha dado mucha satisfacción y oportunidad de trabajar.
texts.en:
Photo, from left to right: María Teresa G. L., Ana Lisbet C. M. and Ángel Lissethe O. M.. The Muñequitas Solidarity Group is composed of María Teresa G. L., Ana Lisbet C. M. and Ángel Lissethe O. M.. Doña María Teresa is the group coordinator. She has a young boy who goes to school. She works at selling clothing on foot; she handles both new and used clothing. She's been engaged in this activity for three years. She is going to use her loan to pay for some orders she has from her customers for Mother's Day. She's going to buy clothing, perfume, shoes, etc. Doña María Teresa is married and her husband helps her with the household expenses, but she likes to have her own business. That way she has her own income and buy herself clothing that she likes. The other member is Doña Ana Lisbet who has been selling pastries for the last two years. She sells these on foot and delivers them to grocery stores. Her business has grown and with her loan she bought a variety of items. That's how she has been able to have more customers. Doña Ángel Lissete sells cosmetics out of the place where she lives. She provides these products to her neighbors and other people in the area. She comments that she used the loan she obtained from ADIM to buy cosmetics and perfumes for orders she had from her customers. The Group hopes always to be a punctual group. This has given them a lot of satisfaction and the opportunity to work.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise for sale.

loans.name: Maria Gregoria

texts.en:
Mrs. Maria Gregoria, age 59, has eight children all of older ages. some of her children are married and no longer live with her. The youngest child is a student and still lives with her. 

She has always liked to be a businesswoman. At first, she worked selling electric house ware over a period of time.  Later, she was authorized to have a place to sell in the galleries of Market 4, where she worked for more than 15 years. After a period of low sales, she decided to sell her spot including the inventory she had at that time. 

With the capital she earned, she opened a restaurant, where her strength was feeding employees of the area. Later, with her husband, she invested in the purchase of properties to sell or to rent, and this way the couple formed their own rental office that operates out of their house. Her husband and children now manage the rental office. In this way she can dedicate herself solely to the restaurant. She feels happy if she can feed 20 people from local businesses and they are happy with what she makes. The credit she receives permits her to better the quality of the services she gives, as well as the quality of life for her family.

loans.use: The purchase of sodas, beers, meats, condiments, etc. and repairs to rental properties.

loans.name: Dopé

texts.fr: Née dans la ville d’agomé séva, cette dame est venu s’installée  depuis 1988 dans la vile de Lomé. Elle est veuve et elle a la charge de ses 4 enfants. L’activité génératrice de revenu qu’elle exerce et qui lui permet de subvenir aux charges de ses enfants est le commerce de charbons de bois. Une partie de son stock a été détruit par la pluie, elle veut se réapprovisionner et sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter 27 sacs de charbons de  bois.
texts.en:
Born in the city of Agomé Séva, this lady came to the city of Lomé in 1998 to get established. She is a widow is alone in caring for her four children. The business that she has for earning an income, and that allows her to provide for her children, is commerce in charcoal. A portion of her inventory was destroyed by the rain. She wants to resupply herself and is requesting her first loan from WAGES to buy 27 sacks of charcoal.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy charcoal

loans.name: Limonario Group

texts.es:
Foto De izquierda a derecha: Norman Alberto J., Sara maría H. R. y Narcisa O. A..

Este es el grupo solidario Limonario, conformado por los señores Norman Alberto J., quien se dedica a la venta de comida y refrescos ya preparados, vende de forma ambulante en la zona de Nindirí, tiene muchos clientes y es conocido por la actividad que realiza, es casado y su esposa elabora parte de los productos que vende, son tacos, enchiladas, pollos rostizados , refrescos naturales etc.

Doña Sara María H. es la coordinadora del grupo,los integrantes la eligieron  para este ciclo, ella vende ropa usada en el mercado oriental de Managua, vende ropa mixta, ropa de primera calidad y de segunda calidad. Tiene tres hijos en edad adolescentes, ellos estudian en la escuela del lugar donde viven y le ayudan a vender en la comunidad y entregan encargos de algunos clientes. Su esposo le ayuda con los gastos del hogar, pero él trabaja independiente.
El crédito lo necesita para comprar dos pacas de ropa de primera ya que tiene encargos y para ofrecerá para las festividades del día de la madre.
Doña Narcisa O. A.  es la ultima integrante de este grupo, ella hace y vende  tortillas comida en su casa por las tardes y por las mañanas vende pan, café y leche en el pueblo. Tiene siete hijos, algunos en edad escolar, otros jóvenes que trabajan en la zona franca y adolescentes que le ayudan a vender en la casa y van a la escuela más cercana, su esposo le ayuda con el gasto, está trabajando en Costa Rica y le envía remesas para que se ayude con los gastos del hogar. Ella sueña crecer en su negocio para salir adelante y poder tener comodidades que le permitan trabajar mejor en su cocina, con el crédito compró inventario como leche, café, azúcar, carnes, verduras y dos mesas para atender a los clientes.

Este grupo es originario de la ciudad de Nindirí, responsables, y semi-analfabetas, pero con muchos deseos de superación. Estos señores abonan todos los Lunes, es el mejor día para abonar, después del fin de semana que las ventas son mejores. 


Trabajan con Adim porque una de las clientas le animó que se integrará en un grupo solidario, así ella conformó su grupo con dos amigas cercanas y obtuvo el préstamo. Están contentos porque sienten que la institución confía en ellas y expresan que se proponen a quedar bien en los pagos.
texts.en:
Photo, left to right: Norman Alberto J., Sara María H. R. and Narcisa O. A.. This is the Limonario Solidarity Group, composed of: Señor Norman Alberto J., who is engaged in the sale of ready-to-eat food and drinks. He sells these on foot in the Nindirí neighborhood. He has lots of customers and is known for his work. He is married and his wife prepares some of the products that he sells, such as tacos, enchiladas, roast chicken, natural beverages, etc. Doña Sara María H. was elected by the Group as their Coordinator for this cycle. She sells used clothing in the Oriental Market in Managua. She sells various types of clothing, the best quality as well as lesser quality. She has three adolescent children. They are attending school near where they live and they help her by selling in the community and taking orders from some of her customers. Her husband helps her with the household expenses but he works independently. She needs the loan to buy two lots of first quality clothing for which she has orders and which she will offer during the Mother's Day festivities. Doña Narcisa O. A. is the last member of this group. She makes and sells tortillas in her house in the afternoon, and in the morning she sells bread, coffee and milk in the town. She has seven children: some are of school age, other youngsters are working in the tax-free area, and her adolescent children help her to sell out of her house and go to school nearby. Her husband helps her with the expenses. He is working in Costa Rica and sends her remittances in order to help her with the household expenses. She dreams of growing her business so she can get ahead and be able to have the amenities that would allow her to work better in her kitchen. She will use the loan to buy ingredients such as milk, coffee, sugar, meats, vegetables and two tables to accommodate her customers. This group originated in the city of Nindirí. They are responsible and semi-literate but they have a great desire to better themselves. These people pay every Monday, which is the best day to make payments, after the weekend when their sales are the best. They are working with ADIM because one of the other clients encouraged them to form a solidarity group. And so Sara organized her group with two close friends and obtained a loan. They are satisfied because they feel that the institution trusts in them and they expressed that they intend to be good with their payments.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various products for sale.

loans.name: Mirtha Beatriz

texts.en:
Mrs. Mirtha V. is 43 years old, is separated, and has one older son that loans his services for a private company.

Ten years ago Mirtha started her business selling cakes, brownies and other pastries among other items in a mini-super market. Thanks to her hard work and dedication, this has grown to be a large grocery store.

She thanks the Foundation for their support.

loans.use: The purchase of materials to make bakery goods (breads, dairy products and meats)

loans.name: Emigdio

texts.en:
Mr. Emigdio P. is 59 years old and has been married to his wife Eusebia for more than 20 years. Together they have six children, all of older ages.

Mr. P. worked for 10 years as an assistant bricklayer, where he learned the profession. Now he is an official building worker. About five years ago he also began selling bedspreads on the street. His clients order the products and then Mr. P. brings the handicrafts to the San Lorenzo district to sell. His wife makes the bedspreads and is in charge of their distribution in order to make a living, and to be able to contribute to the family income. Thanks to her help and sacrifice, they have been able to gather enough resources to start building a modest home.

Mr. P. applies for the loan to buy things to sell, such as hammocks, comforters and sheets.

loans.use: The purchase of goods to sell, such as hammocks, sheets, and blankets.

loans.name: Edoh Abla

texts.fr: Cette dame est une veuve qui pour subvenir aux charges de sa famille, a ouvert une débit de boissons en 2003, elle s’approvisionne auprès de la société de la brasserie"BB" à lomé. Elle livre les boissons aux tenanciers de bars. Une partie de son stock est épuisée, elle veut se réapprovisionner et sollicite de WAGES un premier crédit pour acheter 7 casiers de GUINNESS, 8 casiers de EKU et AWOYO, 15 casiers de sucrerie et autres.
texts.en:
This lady is a widow who opened a drinks depot in 2003 so as to support her family. She gets her merchandise from the brewery BB in Lomé. She delivers drinks to bar owners. A part of her stock is expended, so she needs to stock up and has asked WAGES for a first loan to buy 7 crates of Guinness, 8 crates of Eku and Awoyo, and 15 cases of soft drinks and other items.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of crates of drinks

loans.name: Luis Miguel

texts.en:
Luis Miguel is 36 years old and lives with Vicenta Vera, 30 years old. They live in the city San Ignacio in their own house. They do not have children. 

Luis is the owner of a metalurgy workshop that has been open for more than 10 years. He will use his loan for the purchase of materials for his workshop, such as pipes, metal, and iron sheets, etc.

loans.use: The purchase of raw materials (pipes, metal sheets, etc).

loans.name: Ignacio

texts.es:
Mr. Ignacio B. is 27 years old, single, and lives with his mother in the city of Carapeguá.  

From age 14 he has worked as a street vendor, selling bedspreads that his mother makes.  After six years, he became independent and started to work for himself.  He takes his handicrafts from his district to cell them in the cities Villa Elisa and Asunción.  Ignacio transports them in his truck, which he was able to buy after saving his profits.  In this way he also helps his mother, who is dependent on him.  

He applied for this loan in order to have more capital to invest in the goods he sells, such as hammocks and bedspreads.
texts.en:
Mr. Ignacio B. is 27 years old, single, and lives with his mother in the city of Carapeguá. From age 14 he has worked as a street vendor, selling bedspreads that his mother makes. After six years, he became independent and started to work for himself. He takes his handicrafts from his district to sell them in the cities or Villa Elisa and Asunción. Ignacio transports them in his truck, which he was able to buy after saving his profits. In this way he also helps his mother, who is depends on him financially. He applied for this loan in order to have more capital to invest in the goods he sells, such as hammocks and bedspreads.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of goods to sell such as hammocks and bedspreads.

loans.name: Ibrahima

texts.fr: Ibrahima âgé de quarante quatre (44) ans est un employé d’une usine de  poissonnerie à Mbour. Parallèlement à son emploi un a un taxi qui fait du transport urbain à Mbour les revenus tirés de son taxi lui permettent de compléter son salaires a fin de faire face aux charges du foyer.  Le prêt sollicité lui permet de renouveler l’assurance et vignette du véhicule. A quarante  quatre (44) ans il est père de plusieurs enfants et l’unique travailleur de sa famille.
texts.en:
Ibrahima, 44, is an employee of a fish processing factory in Mbour. Besides this job, he has a taxi for urban transport in Mbour. The income from his taxi allows him to complement his salary so as to support his family. The requested loan will permit him to renew the insurance and sticker for his vehicle. He is the father of several children and the only breadwinner for his family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: paying insurance and sticker fees for his taxi

loans.name: Lirio Del Valle Group

texts.es:
Foto de Izquierda a derecha:   Darling Carolina V. M., Florentina M. D. y María Luisa Z. R..

El grupo solidario Lirio del Valle , está conformado por las siguientes personas: Darling Carolina V. M., Florentina M. D. y María Luisa Z. R..
Doña Darling vende verduras y frutas en el mercado de Masaya, su horario de trabajo es desde temprana horas de la mañana hasta las tres de la tarde que regresa a su casa.Espera poder crecer en su negocio para alcanzar sus metas de mejorar su vivienda.

Doña Florentina vende tortillas que ella misma elabora y destaza cerdo los fines de semana, elabora comidas con la carne del cerdo como: nacatamales, fritos y chicharrones.
Ella es la coordinadora del grupo por ser muy responsable y además tiene el respeto de todos en su comunidad, no tiene hijos a su cargo porque viven independientes, sueña co mejorar su casa y siempre depender de si misma.

Doña María Luisa Z., es una joven mujer, tiene un hijo y vive con su esposo, ella se dedica a la venta de frutas y verduras en el mercado de Masaya, ella trabaja desde muy joven , este oficio lo aprendió de su madre que vende a la par de ella.
Sueña con mejorar su casa y hacer un ahorro para cuando sea una adulta mayor  y así no depender de su hijo y además engrandecer su negocio.

Expresan que en Adim le han enseñado a controlar mejor su negocio con las capacitaciones que reciben y también a mejorar de manera personal.Se proponen trabajar con Adim en varios ciclos y están claras que para esto es solamente si son disciplinadas en sus pagos.
texts.en:
Included in the picture from left to right are the members of the support group "Lirio del Valle" (Lily of the Valley): Darling Carolina V. M., Florentina M. D. and María Luisa Z. R.. Doña Darling sells fruits and vegetables in the Masaya market. She works from early in the morning until 3:00 p.m. and returns home. She hopes to be able to grow her business to be able to reach her goals of improving her home. Doña Florentina sells tortillas that she makes herself and butchers pigs on the weekends. She makes pork dishes such as tamales, pork rinds, and sausages. She is the coordinator of the group because she is very responsible. She also has the respect of everyone in the community. She doesn't have children who depend on her because they now live independently. She dreams about improving her home and always being able to support herself. Doña María Luisa Z. is a young woman who has one son and lives with her husband. She sells fruits and vegetables in the Masaya market. She has worked she she was very young. She learned this business from her mother, who works with her. She dreams about improving her home and have enough savings so that when she is older, she doesn't have to depend on her son. She also wants to expand her business. The members say that Adim has taught them how to better manage their businesses through the training they've received, and also to improve themselves personally. They want to work with Adim for various loan cycles but they know that this will only happen if they are disciplined with their payments.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fruits and vegetables

loans.name: A Primary School In Makeni Ii Group

texts.en:
These are teachers of a Primary School in Makeni. Their school was built in 1985 to help educate the children of Makeni city and its surrounding villages. The school has a total of twelve staff and 450 pupils.

Teachers are one of the lowest paid workers in Sierra Leone. Because of this, many of them find other additional means of making a living. Some engage in businesses or agriculture and others organized extra classes for the pupils (though this is a practice the government is trying to abolish). Teachers therefore seek a loan in order to embark on meaningful projects and then, out of their monthly salaries, they gradually repay the loan.

Mabel C. (second from right) is a senior teacher at the school and head of this group. She is age forty-five. She was born in Matamp village in the Tonkolili district, in northern Sierra Leone. She is married to a teacher and they have four children together. One of her children is already a grown-up and training as a lab technician, while two others (the twins) are in Junior Secondary School III (JSS III) and the last is in JSS I.

Mabel has been a teacher for over twenty-five years now. She will use this loan to buy a piece of land for the purpose of constructing a house. Buying a plot of land will improve her life, she told me. With subsequent loans, and with the little she has and will be saving, she will be able to build her house. She needs a home for her children and for her old age.

loans.use: To buy a plot of land for constructing a house

loans.name: Maria Asunción

texts.en:
Mrs. Maria Asunción D. is 56 years old and she has lived in San Ignacio for more than 25 years. She is married with two older children that are working professionals. Her spouse owns a truck which he uses as a taxi, in order to contribute to the family income.

Maria is the owner of "Casa Rodi," which has been open for more than 15 years. She is in charge of running the business, where she sells different clothing items and shoes such as t-shirts, jeans, sandals, sneakers, coats, and so on, for both children and adults. She has a high level of sales due to a good amount of attention the store brings and good prices.

She will use this loan to buy coats, pullovers, shirts and pants for the fall and winter seasons.

loans.use: To buy autumn jackets and pullovers.

loans.name: Kouma

texts.fr:
Cette femme exerce comme activité la vente de produits alimentaires, elle est très dynamique, elle est souvent rare de voir les hommes   faire ce genre de commerce. Elle  conquiert  tous les jours de nouveaux clients. Elle  veut agrandir son commerce en y associant la vente de céréales afin de réaliser plus de recettes. Elle sollicite alors de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter 10 sacs d’haricots, 10 sacs de mil, 5 paniers moyens de piments verts, 1 grand panier de tomates et divers produits alimentaires.
Elle est mariée et mère de 04 enfants
texts.en:
This lady sells groceries; she is very energetic and gains new customers daily. She wants to expand her business and add to sale of cereals so as to make more money. She is therefore asking WAGES for her first loan to buy 10 sacks of dried beans, 10 sacks of millet, 5 medium-sized baskets of green peppers, 1 big basket of tomatoes, and other grocery items.

She is married and the mother of 4 children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of cereals and other grocery items for resale

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort O. is 54 years of age. She is married and has given birth to five children – one daughter and four sons. She says the last born is currently in the senior high school while the rest are out of school. She lives with her husband and children in a family house in a very busy commercial town called Goaso in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana.

Comfort is a trader. She trades in groundnut paste. She buys bags of fresh groundnut from nearby farming communities, which she roasts and sends to the mill and sells in a pan on a table top at the community market. She supplies food vendors in her community and treks to other towns to sell on their market days as well. Comfort also sells other food items.

She has been in this business for one year now and wants a loan to procure bags of groundnut in bulk. She hopes to expand her business and increase her profit margin to be able to help her husband provide for the family.

loans.use: To buy bags of groundnuts

loans.name: Adriana

texts.en:
Mrs. Adriana Arana is 32 years old and is married to Mr. Miguel Denis. Together they have a young daughter and live in the city of Carapeguá, in the neighborhood of San Miguel. 

Adriana is a street vender who dedicates herself to the buying and selling of different articles during the weekend when she works with her husband. The rest of the week she works as a manicurist.

Because she was orphaned at a young age, Adriana began to work very young as she is the oldest of all of her siblings and she was in charge of taking care of the rest of them.

Adriana applied for a loan with Fundación Paraguaya to buy more merchandise to sell.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise to sell

loans.name: Anelsma Elsa

texts.en:
Mrs. Anselma is the owner of a small grocery store. She is married to Mr. Teofile Fernandez, but they do not have children. They live in the city San Ignacio.

The loan was used by Mrs. Anselma to buy goods for the grocery store that she runs from her home. Because there is a large construction project in the area, there are a lot of workers in the area that buy from Mrs. Anselma’s store.

loans.use: To purchase goods for her grocery store

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia K., 41 years of age, is a married mother of four children – two sons and two daughters. She tells us that her children are in senior high, junior high and the primary schools. She lives with the children and her husband in a very busy commercial town called Goaso, in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. Her husband is a teacher. Felicia is a trader. She works very hard to help her husband provide for the family. She trades in children’s wear and ladies’ underwear. She buys from Kumasi and sells on a tabletop in her community market. Felicia says she also treks to other towns to sell on their market days. She has been in business for over twenty years. She is hopeful to expand her business and increase her profit margin. It is her desire to sponsor her children in school to high levels.

loans.use: To buy ladies’ wear.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica A. bakes and sells bread in Abura. Monica has received schooling through Junior High. She is married and has 4 dependants. Monica has been baking and selling bread for 2 years. She is responsible for paying all of the housekeeping expenses. Her loan will be used to buy flour and other ingredients for baking. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to re-invest.

loans.use: To buy flour and other ingredients for baking.

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia A. is fifty years old. She is married and has given birth to three children: two sons and one daughter. She says they are in senior high school and the polytechnic. She lives with the children and her husband in a rented apartment in a very busy commercial town called Goaso, in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. Felicia’s husband is a teacher while she is a trader. She works very hard to help her husband to provide for the family. Felicia trades in groundnut paste. 
She buys bags of fresh groundnut from Kumasi and sells on a tabletop in her community market. Felicia says she also treks to other towns to sell on their market days. She has been in business for over thirty years. She is hopeful to expand her business and increase her profit margin. Felicia desires to sponsor her children in school to high levels.

loans.use: To buy bags of groundnut.

loans.name: Efuah

texts.en: Efuah N. is married and has 2 children. She has not received any formal education. Efuah sells smoked fish in a very small quantity in Abura, which she has done for 15 years. Her husband is a cleaner who provides a small income, which cannot support the needs of the family. Efuah uses all her income for feeding the entire family and paying for school fees for the children. Efuah will use the loan to purchase fish, process and sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Efuah plans to re-invest.

loans.use: To purchase fish, process and sell.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica D. is 38 years of age. She is single and has no children. She says she lives with her mother in a family house in a very busy commercial town called Goaso, in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. Monica is a trader. She trades in groundnut paste. She buys bags of fresh groundnut from nearby farming communities, roasts it, sends it to the mill and sells the paste on a tabletop at the community market. She also supplies to food vendors in her community and treks to other towns to sell on their market days. Monica also sells other food items in addition to the groundnut paste. She has been in business for three years and wants a loan to procure bags of groundnut in bulk. She is hopeful to expand her business and increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To buy bags of groundnuts in bulk to sell.

loans.name: Kennedy

texts.en:
Kennedy O. is twenty-six years old. He is single and has no child. He lives independently in a rented apartment in Goaso in the Brong Ahafo Region. Goaso is one of the busy business centres in the region.

Kennedy is into agro-chemicals trading. He sells all kinds of chemicals – pesticides, insecticides, fertilizers, etc., in a store at the community market. He buys his chemicals from big shops in nearby towns such as Kumasi.

Kennedy has been in business for two years and wants a loan to procure many types of agro-chemicals. He is hopeful to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy more agro-chemicals to sell

loans.name: Las Vecinas Group

texts.es:
Foto de Izquierda a derecha: Margarita Antonia R., Esther B. H. y Maritza del Socorro O. G..

Llegaron a tener crédito con Adim porque una cliente les habló del tipo de crédito que recibían, donde confiaban en la honorabilidad de los clientes.

Este grupo es originario de la ciudad de Masaya, de la comarca de San Ramón                                    está conformado por las siguientes personas:
Doña Margarita  vende frutas y verduras en su casa, ofrece frutas de la temporada que son las más baratas, compra en el mercado y las vende al detalle donde saca mejores ganancias , es casada, madre de dos hijos jóvenes que trabajan independientes, ya no estudian, llegaron hasta la secundaria.

Doña Esther Baltonano, es otra de las integrantes, ella también vende verduras ambulante, vende frutas peladas y entrega a clientes fijos, ella es conocida por vendedora en la comunidad, compra en Masaya al por mayor y  al detalle. Tiene  
 dos hijos pequeños que estudian en la escuela más cercana a su casa, ella se encarga de cuidarlos y desea que terminen estudios para que conozcan cosas que ella no conoce

Doña Maritaza del Socorro es  la coordinadora del grupo, es una joven mujer madre de dos niños de edad escolar, tiene un pequeño puesto en el mercado de Tipitapa, trabaja desde muy tempranas horas y regresa a horas de la tarde para dar atención a los niños y hacer los oficios del hogar. Sueña dar estudio a sus hijos y mejorar su vivienda, expresa que esta contenta de trabajar con Adim porque ella nunca había tenido oportunidad de un crédito por no tener garantías y ahora ella va a quedar bien a la institución que confía en ella.

Estos señoras abonan todos los Lunes, es el mejor día para abonar, después del fin de semana que las ventas son mejores y así garantizan la cuota del préstamo.
texts.en:
Photograph from left to right: Margarita Antonia R., Esther B. H. and Maritza del Socorro O. G.. The ended up involved with Adim because another person told them about the types of loans they received from an organization with confidence in the honor of its participants. This group originates in the city of Masay, located in the San Ramón region, and is comprised of the following members: Margarita sells fruits and vegetables from her home. She offers fruit during the season when they are the cheapest. She buys them at the market then sells them at retail, which is when she can garner a better profit. She is married and the mother of two young sons who work independently. They are no longer in school, but completed their educations up to secondary school. Esther B., another member, also sells vegetables and peeled fruit that she markets to repeat customers. She is known as a merchant throughout the community. She buys her products in Masaya both at wholesale and at retail. She has two young sons who study at the school closest to her house. She wants them to finish their educations so they can have opportunities that she has never known. Maritza del Socorro is the coordinator of the group. She is a young mother of two school-aged children. She has a small stall in the Tipitapa market and works from early in the morning, returning home in the afternoon to care for her children and tend to the home. She dreams of providing educations for her children and of making improvements to her house. She notes that she is happy to work with Adim because she has never had the opportunity to obtain financing due to lack of collateral. Now, she is going to do right by the institution that has shown confidence in her abilities. These women take credit on Mondays, which they consider the best day to do so. After the weekend, sales are better, and this way they secure the installment payment toward the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary B. is thirty-eight years of age, married, and currently has no child. She says she lives with her husband in a rented apartment in a very busy commercial town called Goaso in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana.

Mary trades in eggs. She buys crates of eggs from nearby poultry farming communities and sells them on a table at the community market. She also supplies to food vendors in her community and treks to other towns to sell on their market days as well.

Mary has been in business for over fifteen years and wants a loan to procure crates of eggs in bulk. She is hopeful to expand her business and increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To buy crates of eggs in bulk

loans.name: Comunitarios Monkey Point. Group

texts.es:
En Monkey Point, kriol comunidad del Territorio Rama y Kriol de la Región Autónoma Atlántica Sur (RAAS) de Nicaragua, ubicada en la Costa Caribeña a unas dos horas en panga con motor fuera de borda, los comunitarios no tienen acceso directo a la luz eléctrica.
Gracia a los grandes esfuerzos de los líderes kriol en el desarrollo de la comunidad, los comunitarios están ahora siendo beneficiados con materiales eléctricos como una batería ciclo profundo la cual se carga en un centro comunal de carga alimentado por un sistema hibrido eólico-solar o con sistema solar individual de 14 W.

Por razón de costos de inversión muy elevados, blueEnergy y ADEPHCA-KIVA en constante y fuerte coordinación con el local kriol gobierno comunal (la organización comunal local que se encarga de todos los asuntos de la comunidad) están buscando financiamiento a traves de los créditos de Kiva para la compra de los materiales eléctricos que consisten en lo siguiente:

- Un controlador de carga de un valor de $28 USD, una batería de un valor de $152 USD, dos bujías de 11 Watt de un valor de $17 USD, cable eléctrico #14 que cuesta $15 USD y otros pequeños equipos (caja de Madera, fusible, enchufes, interruptores, toma, etc.) que dan un costo total del sistema de luz de aproximadamente de $290.15 USD por beneficiario.
- O un sistema individual solar que consiste en un panel solar, una pequeña batería 12V/7Ah, un controlador de carga, bujías, cables, etc. que al final dan un costo total del sistema de $241.81 USD. (* los precios fueron estimados después de las compras).

Un grupo de 10 personas son beneficiarios de micro-crédito grupal de Kiva. Del costo total, los beneficiarios pagan $65 USD y así asumen 22% o 27% de este costo total dependiendo del sistema, la otra parte siendo subsidiada por un proyecto. Ellos se organizaron y eligieron un responsable del seguimiento del micro-crédito en la comunidad: Gloria S., y una persona responsable de llevar el dinero del crédito a la oficina de ADEPHCA en Bluefields: Rito A..
Se anota que algunos de los beneficiarios no son en la foto porque eran trabajando.

Se espera con este financiamiento que les permita a los beneficiarios poder aprovechar la luz eléctrica para mejorar su nivel de vida y aprovechar para de la noche en sus quehaceres diarios.
texts.en:
In Monkey Point, kriol community of the Rama and Kriol Territory from the South Atlantic Autonomous Region (RAAS) of Nicaragua, located on the Caribbean Coast two hours offshore by panga (motorized boat), people do not benefit of a direct access to electricity. Thanks to the strong involvement of the kriol leaders in the development of the community, the community people are now being benefited by electrical materials such as deep-cycled battery charged in a charging station supplied by a hybrid wind-solar system or small individual solar systems of 14W. For high investment cost, blueEnergy and ADEPHCA-Kiva in constant and strong coordination with the local kriol community board (the local communal organization that deals with all the issues of the community) are seeking financing through Kiva loans to acquire these electrical supplies such as: - A charge controller that costs $28 USD, a battery that costs $152 USD, two 11 Watt bulb that costs $17 USD, #14 electrical wire that costs $15 USD and other small pieces (wood box, fusible, sparkplug, interrupters, sockets, etc.) that raises the total cost of the system to approximately to $290.15 USD per beneficiary. - Or for the individual small solar system composed of one panel, one small 12V/7Ah battery, charge controller, bulbs, cables, etc. that brings the total price of the system to $241.81 USD. (* prices valued after the purchase). A group of 10 persons are beneficiaries of this Kiva group credit. From the total system cost, the community people are only paying $65 USD, representing 22% or 27% of this total cost depending on the system, the other part being subsidized by a project. They get organized and have a person responsible in the community to follow the micro-credit, Gloria S., and one person responding to bring the money in the ADEPHCA office in Bluefields, Rito A.. It should be noted that some of the beneficiaries does not appear on the photograph as, at the time it was taken they were out of the community for working reasons. It is hoped that this financing will permit the beneficiaries to take advantage of electrical lighting to use some of the evening hours for taking care of their household chores.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Electrical supplies.

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Eric A. is thirty-nine years old, married and has three children: two sons and a daughter. All are currently in the primary school. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in Goaso in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. Goaso is one of the busy business centres in the region. His wife trades in vegetables.

Eric trades in roofing sheets and sells in a shop by the roadside. He buys packets of roofing sheets from big shops in nearby towns such as Kumasi.

Eric has been in business for two years and wants a loan to procure roofing sheets in large quantity. He is hopeful to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy roofing sheets in large quantity

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John O. is fifty-three years old, married, and has four children: three sons and a daughter. Some are in the senior high school while others are in the junior high and the primary schools. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in Goaso in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. Goaso is one of the busy business centres in the region. John’s wife is a trader.

John deals in hardware – paints, glue, locks, carpentry tools, etc. which he sells in a shop by the roadside. John buys his wares from big shops in nearby towns such as Kumasi. He has been in business for over twenty years and wants a loan to procure goods in large quantity. He is hopeful to expand his business and give his children a good education.

loans.use: To buy hardware in large quantity

loans.name: María Isabel Group

texts.es:
Foto de Izquierda a derecha: Irenia del Carmen L., Ignacia  de los Santos P. y Flora Isabel S. A..

 Este grupo tiene su domicilio en  la ciudad de Masaya en comarca Las conchitas, estas tres mujeres tienen actividades comerciales diferentes, se conocen desde hace muchos años y tienen una gran confianza una en la otra. 

Doña Irenia vende perecederos en el mercado de Masaya, vende frutas, las compra al por mayor y ella vende al detalle durante el día, tiene un hijo de 12 años que va a la escuela, su esposo es comerciante en el mismo mercado donde acarrea productos, le ayuda con los gastos del hogar.
Se dedica desde muy joven a su actividad comercial y ella piensa hacer crecer su negocio y así un día mejorar su casa.

Doña Ignacia es la coordinadora del grupo, ella tiene un puesto de perecederos en el mercado donde ofrece productos como: chayotes,  ayotes , sandías etc., sueña con terminar la casa que están construyendo en terreno propio y muy pronto trasladarse a vivir ahí.
No tiene dependientes ni esposo, ella vive con su mamá y se propone hacer crecer el negocio para salir adelante.

Doña María Isabel al igual que las otras dos se dedica a la misma actividad, ella es la más joven y tiene tres hijos pequeños, vive con su esposo y están terminando de comprar un terreno para un día construir su casa.
Ella invierte el crédito en comprar verduras que vienen de la zona norte del país.

Expresan que en Adim le han enseñado a controlar mejor su negocio con las capacitaciones que reciben y también a mejorar de manera personal.
texts.en:
Photograph from left to right: Irenia del Carmen L., Ignacia de los Santos P. and Flora Isabel S. A.. This group is domiciled in the city of Masaya, in the Las Conchitas region. These three women undertake different commercial activities, have known each other for many years, and have great confidence in each other. Irenia sells perishables in the market of Masaya. She sells fruit that she buys at wholesale, and then sells at retail during the day. She has one son who is 12 years old and in school. Her husband is a merchant at the same market, where they transport their products, and helps with the household expenses. She has dedicated herself from a young age to her commercial activities, and she plans to make her business grow so she can one day make improvements to her house. Ignacia is the coordinator of the group, and has a stand of perishable goods at the market where she offers products such as: chayotes, ayotes, watermelons, etc. She dreams of finishing the home they are building on land they own, and move there very soon to live. She has no dependents or husband. She lives with her mother, and she proposes to make her business grow so she can get ahead. María Isabel dedicates herself to the same activity as the others. She is the youngest member, and has three small children. She lives with her husband, and they are completing the purchase of some land where they can one day build their house. She invests her loan into purchasing vegetables that come from the northern part of the country. They express that Adim has taught them how to better manage their businesses utilizing the help they receive, and also how to advance on a personal level. It is hoped that this financing will allow them to benefit from access to electrical power, which will help improve their standard of living and afford them part of the evening hours to tend to household chores.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Diametesadik Group

texts.fr: Le groupe Diametesadik regroupe cinq (5) vendeurs de légumes et condiment d’un marché de quartier de la ville de Mbour. Le groupe crée depuis deux (2) ans permette à ses membres de réunir chaque jour des cotisations de cent fracs CFA qui sont versées chaque jour à un membre du groupe à tour de rôle. Cette somme est injectée dans le commerce pour renforcer le fonds de roulement du groupe. Face à l’insuffisance ses cotisations à régler leurs besoins en fonds de roulement, le groupe  sollicite un prêt. La plus part des membres du groupe ont quitté leur village pour s’installer à la ville à fin d’avoir de quoi nourrir leur famille.
texts.en:
The Diametesadik group unites 5 vegetable and condiment sellers from a neighborhood market in the town of Mbour. This group, which was created 2 years ago, permits its members to come up with daily dues in the amount of 100 francs CFA, which is then paid out daily to each member in turn. This sum is injected into the business to bolster the working capital of the group. Since the amount of dues is not sufficient for their needs in terms of working capital, the group is requesting a loan. Most of the members of the group left their villages to come live in the town so that they could feed their families.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital for their little businesses

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence D. is fifty-four years old. She is a widowed mother of six children: four sons and two daughters. Some are in the tertiary while others are in the senior high schools. She lives with the children in a rented apartment in a very busy commercial town called Goaso in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana.

Florence is a trader. She works very hard to provide for the family. She trades in groundnut paste (peanut butter) and other food items such as vegetables, oil, spices, etc. She buys bags of fresh groundnuts from Kumasi and sells on a table in her community market. Florence says she also treks to other towns to sell on their market days.

Florence has been in business for over twenty years. She is hopeful to expand her business and increase her profit margin. Florence desires to sponsor her children in school to high levels.

loans.use: To buy bags of groundnuts

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en:
Faustina A. is forty-two years old. She is married and has given birth to three children: one son and two daughters. Some are in the senior high school while others are in the junior high school. She lives with the children and her husband in a rented apartment in a very busy commercial town called Goaso in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. Her husband is a trader.

Faustina is a trader. She works very hard to help her husband to provide for the family.
